instruction: Please simulate consumer 'erene collins' to comment on the product 'Magic Bullet Blender, Small, Silver, 11 Piece Set'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 39.88; Brand: Magic Bullet; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Blenders:Countertop Blenders'.
output: Purchase Great: Work great

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Meg' to comment on the product 'Magic Bullet Blender, Small, Silver, 11 Piece Set'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 39.88; Brand: Magic Bullet; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Blenders:Countertop Blenders'.
output:
I really wanted to love this but it wasn’t powerful enough: Pros: tiny footprint (good for my tiny kitchen); incredibly easy to use; great accessory package
Cons: not very powerful, small size of containers means you can’t really use it for two people

I love love love it for its cuteness and tiny footprint. It did ok with spinach (still specks of green but the texture was fine). They say it doesn’t work with frozen things, but I added frozen banana and mango (small chunks) and it worked fine. So for simple smoothies, it’s probably good (no celery, no mature greens, but that’s not a big deal to me, and I definitely wouldn’t use ice.). The capacity is a bit too small—you can only get one large smoothie out of it, or two 6 to 7 oz ones. It does come with multiple cups, so you could make two separate ones.

However, I was hoping to dump my virtually unused, large, pain to clean blender and use this for all cold things. Nope. Virtually the only thing I use the blender for is pesto. The Magic Bullet was an epic fail at that. There was no way to get it to process the basil leaves, likely because pesto doesn’t take a lot of liquid.

The 600 watt Nutribullet, which I found had some other issues, blended the pesto well (as with a blender, it ended up a bit over processed but tasty). That level of power is, a bit sadly, what I need.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Sara McKercher' to comment on the product 'Omega Nutrition Center Juicer (Discontinued by Manufacturer)'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 279.98; Brand: Omega; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Masticating Juicers'.
output: This juicer is the Bomb!: I ordered the Omega Juicer as a birthday present for myself.  So far, I'm loving it!  It does exactly what it's supposed to do.  This is my first juicer, so I don't have anything to compare it to, but I think it produces a LOT of juice.  The pulp that comes out is dry and the juice is delicious!  I've juiced all sorts of fruits, veggies and leafy greens, and it handles them all wonderfully.  It's so easy to set up and use, and it's fun.  My two-year old even helps me make juice.  He sits on the counter and drops the produce in and uses the plunger to mash it down the chute.  I'm so excited to be able to make him fresh, healthy juice.  One of his favorites so far is 2 apples, a kiwi and a handful of spinach.  Clean up is super easy too.  Just disassemble the parts and rinse in warm water.  Done!  I truly love this machine!  I get excited just thinking about what kinds of juice I will make next.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Matthew Freed' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart CRC-400P1 4 Cup Rice Cooker, Stainless Steel Exterior'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: I don't feel like washing an extra item so I skip the steam ...: As many other reviewers will tell you, this rice cooker has boil-over issues if you don't have the steam tray in place. I'm a lazy cook; I don't feel like washing an extra item so I skip the steam tray. Instead, before I set the lid on I give a quick spray on the inside walls of the cooking vessel with non-stick spray. This achieves the same effect by preventing foam from being able to climb up the sides of the pot. Plus, if you use olive oil spray it adds a little flavor.Major con:The lid is not well-built. It's annoying to clean inside the rim and you have to disassemble the knob to properly clean under it. The black part of the knob where the screw locks in is cheap plastic and it cracked after 6 months. Now, I can't get a tight lock. Sometimes, holding the handle by the knob is enough for the weight of the lid to pull the screw right out. This, of course, is a real pain when you have a hot lid. You can order a replacement lid assembly for about $15 from Cuisinart's parts department, but it feels like a ripoff. If it had a better lid, 4 stars.If you can get past that, it makes great rice every time. I even like to sweat diced onions and peppers in the pot before adding the rice and liquid.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Dawn' to comment on the product 'Omega Nutrition Center Juicer (Discontinued by Manufacturer)'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 279.98; Brand: Omega; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Masticating Juicers'.
output: Juicer and More: I just got this yesterday, but I've already used it twice and it is a great juicer.  So quiet!!  You have to make sure you read the instructions because if you don't alternate the soft and the harder fruit and veggies, the soft will get clogged in the grinder.  You need that harder material to go through to push out the soft pulps.  I'm a beginner juicer and was borrowing my sister's juicer which was a GE.  The Omega is much sturdier and does not jump around like the GE and so much quieter than the GE which sounds like jet engines.  I like the feeder shoot on the Omega, nothing comes flying out of it like the GE.  The clean up is easier with the Omega and it is easy to put together and take apart.  And, I love the fold down handle on the top, so much easier to move around.  Also, there are so many different tips for different functions that I have not even begun to figure out but it looks like it can be used as a shreader/dicer/chopper as well.  Happy Juicing!!!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'KAREN S.' to comment on the product 'Presto Salad Shooter Electric Slicer/Shredder,White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Electric Utensils:Electric Slicers'.
output: Great Appliance, but Disappointed: I have owned a Presto Salad Shooter since the early 80's. I love it and use it all the time. So, I decided to get another for my second home, as I had been carrying my old one back and forth. First time I used it was to shred carrots for salad. Worked great until it came time to clean it. Everywhere the carrot touched is now stained orange. I soaked it in Dawn and even put it in the dishwasher...it still came out orange. My 40-year-old Salad Shooter doesn't have any stains on it. What is the problem!? So every food it contacts is going to absorb food juices? How is that healthy and/or safe. I am very disappointed in a product that has been my right hand for decades and still works great. Apparently the new one is being made from different materials. I'm not using an appliance that absorbs and holds food matter that easily.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Chelsea keller' to comment on the product 'Presto 03430 Pizzazz Plus Rotating Oven, Black'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 79.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Ovens & Toasters:Countertop Pizza Ovens'.
output: Love this can’t go without now!: I was actually pretty impressed with this product. My oven stopped working but my stove top still worked fine so I didn’t want to deal with replacing yet. I didn’t use it much anyway but still wanted something I could use now and then for frozen pizza and such. I wasn’t sure what to expect with how it cooked pizza and stuff but was super impressed. The crust does get crispy which I was worried about and the top is also cooked perfectly. I think it actually does better than the oven and the temp seems more controlled with this device so it cooks super evenly. And it came with time suggestions in the manual that were very accurate which was great. This is actually a super versatile small appliance that you can cook a surprising variety of foods on. Over all super happy with it and it was like 25$ cheaper on here than the other cheapest place I could find it!!!!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Muggs' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Still going strong after years of use: I've used this cooker constantly for rice and steel cut oats for about 3 years.  I admit that I use only the plastic spatula that came with it to serve the rice and the bowl has held up very nicely.  I see that there are some people who complain about scratching and I have to wonder what they're using in the bowl.  Yes, my old rice cooker did a fine job of cooking rice, but we love being able to program this and wake to the smell of hot oatmeal just when we want it.  I also enjoy setting it up to be finished just as guests arrive for dinner.  I'm just about to order another one for a very special friend. I gave one to my mother last year and she's used it constantly (3 - 4x/week) without any problems.  I've had no problems in the years I've owned this product.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'J.' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Breville Juice Fountain Elite 800JEXL: Both my wife and I wanted to start juicing to improve our health, reduce the amount of processed food we consumed and loose weight.  After reading online reviews and because I like to buy things once, I chose the 800JEXL.  Once you get your juicing routine, it is easy to dissemble and clean.  The stainless steel juice collector does not stain and is dishwasher safe (unlike the plastic collectors).  The juicing blade is supposed to be titanium reinforced.  While I can't tell looking at it, the titanium should keep the blades sharp much, much longer.  I looks well built. Looks good on your counter (because it is big) and goes through anything we've put in in like butter.  Only downside, is it's pricey, but as they say, you get what you pay for.

instruction: Please simulate consumer '©ooper' to comment on the product 'Hamilton Beach DrinkMaster Electric Drink Mixer, Restaurant-Quality Retro Milkshake Maker & Milk Frother, 2 Speeds, Extra-Large 28 oz. Stainless Steel Cup, Classic Chrome'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Hamilton Beach; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Mixers:Stand Mixers'.
output: Malted Milkshake Heaven: This is not just another blender. It makes milkshakes unlike traditional blenders, much to my surprise. It’s not as large as I’d like. You can’t make 28oz shakes, more like 12 because of the way it whips up the ice cream. And you can’t just turn it on and not hold it. It feels like if you do, it’ll rattle off and spill all over. Not anxious to find out if I’m wrong. Although they never held onto to the cup when you got one at the diner.But it works like it should and looks nice on the countertop, like you mean business.Update 12/2020: having used this almost daily to satisfy my malted milkshake addiction, I’ve found the motor rattles terribly when mixing milkshakes. I thought it was defective, but more likely the thickness of the mixture sticking to the plastic agitator. I’m at the end of my return window, and don’t think replacing it might solve the problem. They make one that looks similar, and appears to have a metal tip (model 65120), but is more than twice the price. They also make a commercial grade model (HMD200), but that one is well in excess of $300.Will see how long this one lasts, and then consider the alternatives. instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Brittaney ' to comment on the product 'Proctor Silex Durable Electric Vegetable Chopper & Mini Food Processor for Chopping, Puree & Emulsify, 1.5 Cup, White'. output: You Get What You Pay For: To say I’m disappointed in this product would be an understatement. Especially since it specifically advertises making baby food. I bought this food processor specifically to make homemade baby food only. It’s pretty simple to use once you figure it out, it’s easy to clean, but unfortunately the positives of the product end here...When i used it for the first time i was trying to purée butternut squash. I chopped it up into little pieces, boiled it to make it soft, then stuck it in the processor. I ran it for several minutes, stopping frequently to stir with a spoon, and it still came out very chunky. Chunks so little they aren’t easily identifiable, but large enough to make my daughter choke. If you’re thinking about getting this to make homemade baby food, don’t. It is a choking hazard.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Bill Sullivan' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Juicing Pomegranate Seeds: I was hoping that this juicer would work on pomegranate seeds. I have a tree and use the seed juice to make jelly. I had been using a hand press that did a very good job but is messy and labor intensive. The Breville Elite is well made and easy to clean, but I have to put the seed pulp through a second time to get the maximum amount of juice from the seeds. The juice is cloudy and foamy and I will have to filter it to get a bright, clear juice. All-in-all, however, it is fast and even the second processing makes the job much faster and easier than the hand press.I realize that juicing pomegranate seeds is not the usual function of this machine and that it can not be adequately judged on this basis. I cannot say whether there is a machine out there that would do a better job with this fruit. I will be trying some juice recipes to take full advantage of my purchase.The unit is sturdy and clean-up is fast and easy. It does have a rather large footprint and is heavy, so storage is something to be considered.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Miss Pudin' to comment on the product 'BLACK+DECKER G48TD Waffle Maker, 3-in-1, Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 69.99; Brand: BLACK+DECKER; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: Made half baked waffles: It looks nice but that's about it.  When I first touched the handle to add the batter it was extremely hot. I was surprised my fingers weren't burned.  I made two waffles. Both came out with part of the waffle cooked correctly and the other half barely done...a very pale brown.  I will be exchanging it for a second small round Cuisinart waffle maker like the one I currently have and just have both cooking at the same time.  It works great and is $30!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Doug Bittinger' to comment on the product 'Emerson 0.7 CU. FT. 700 Watt, Touch Control, Black Microwave Oven, MW7302B'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 71.31; Brand: Emerson; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Microwave Ovens:Countertop Microwave Ovens'.
output: Convenient for a single person: I bought this microwave as a replacement for the Emerson microwave I have been using for twenty years or more!  That one's electronics finally gave out, but I wanted another Emerson.I did not want one with all the complicated air fryer, convection, I'll-even-do-the-dishes features.  The more complicated a thing is, the easier it is to break.  So far, I am happy with my choice.The only down side is that the printing on the control panel membrane is difficult to see.  At least it is for my 67 year old eyes.This one puts out half as many watts of power as the bigger Emerson it replaced, but by adjusting my cooking times it works just as well.It is a small microwave, so don't think you'll cook a turkey in here.  but the interior design is such that it maximizes the amount of room for things to spin as they cook.The instant cook buttons are handy.  Want to warm something for 2 minutes, just press the 2, without pressing anything else first, and the oven will run at full power for 2 minutes.  The 1 through 6 buttons are set up this way.  Or you can program it to cook for a specific time, like 1½ minutes at full power or at a lower power by using the Power button.The manual is pretty clear in its instruction, so it took me only a few minutes to learn the functions I use all the time.I doubt this one will also last me 20 years, but I'm hoping Emerson Electric has provided another sturdy appliance.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'StayFit' to comment on the product 'Aroma Housewares ASP-137 Grillet 3Qt. 3-in-1 Cool-Touch Electric Indoor Grill Portable, Dishwasher Safe, 3-Quart, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 31.1; Brand: Aroma Housewares; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Indoor Grills & Griddles:Electric Grills'.
output: Really great little indoor grill!!: I really like this little grill.  It is the perfect size (not too big and not too small) for making all sorts of different things.  I love having the option of grilling but also using it as a slow cooker and skillet etc...So far I've tried chicken, hambergers, veggies, turkey sausage and they have all turned out really good.  I can fit about two chicken breasts in there or 3 small - medium sized burgers, to give you an idea of the size.  Just be aware that you need to really monitor the temp as it gets really hot really fast and it can burn things if you aren't watching it. Start with a little lower temp and then gradually move up if needed.  On the flip side, i love how quickly it heats up and how it cooks things thru when you put the lid on it.  The chicken flavor reminded me of how it would be on a gas grill outdoors.  Also, I love how easy this is to clean.  Other grills I've had in the past were awful and this one all comes apart and fits right in my sink and because of the non-stick coating, it really makes cleaning a breeze. (I have not tried it in the dishwasher and would not recommend doing that other than the glass lid) The white plastic holder does seem a little cheap but it's holding up ok so far.  Truthfully, this is the best indoor grill I've ever had.  While I can't speak to the longevity of it, I can speak to the fact that at this point in time it works and works very well.  Would highly recommend.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'CDubya' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Best Rice Ever.: Okay, I lived in Japan for 10+ years, and have been visiting there for over 30 years, so I have eaten a lot of rice in my time. In all honesty, I'm not even that crazy about rice. Being a former baker, I much prefer bread, and over all this time have always thought that rice is rice, you know what I mean?Since I moved back to the U.S. about five years ago, I used a cheap rice cooker/steamer/yogurt maker from Costco. It did the job, and cooked rice fairly adequately. It died on me last year, though, and my wife BEGGED me to buy a quality rice cooker to replace it. Though a cheapskate at heart, I'm also a big softie, so after spending hours online researching rice cookers in English and Japanese, we settled on the 5.5 cup model of this one. It lacks all the bells and whistles of higher end suihanki, but it has high reviews, the most modern technology and design features to cook rice well, and Zojirushi is one of the most trusted brands in Japan.As much as I have wanted to believe that my wife was over finicky about rice (typical male?), I am not too proud to admit when I am wrong. I was so wrong - the rice that this appliance cooks is truly phenomenal! Whereas the rice in the previous cooker had soft and hard spots - some rice overcooked and some undercooked - the rice from this one is uniformly consistent. Each grain comes out glossy and chewy, with just the right amount of stickiness.If you want to make any popular Japanese dishes, from the lowly onigiri (rice balls), to sushi - everything turns out more delicious with rice from this cooker. I truly don't understand how there can be such an immediate, explicit difference in the quality of the cooked rice. We use the same exact brand of rice every time, and my wife doesn't even use any of the "fancy" features on the device - she just hits "quick rice."Nearly two hundred dollars may seem like an exorbitant amount to spend on a one-trick pony appliance like this (especially considering our bread machine was only around 50 bucks). Rest assured, though, this is money well spent. I cannot recommend this rice cooker enough.

output: Always the same malfunction: It's a bit embarrassing to admit, but somehow I've gone through 4 of these exact same rice cookers. They always break in the same way, but they're just so darn cute that I keep purchasing them! Two of them lived longer than 6 years, but the other two died within 20 uses. instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Zoe K' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: LOVE MY RICE: It is pricey...but OOOOhhh it is good. I've struggled with rice on stove top for years and refused to buy any rice maker on principle. I finally gave in and this was the winner. I got it based on the reviews, its cool egg shape, and did I mention the reviews. I attest: all the positive, raving ones are true.It is hard to mess up rice in this puppy. I've tried different settings, types of rice, mixed in veggies (frozen and fresh) and have loved ALL results.Is the music irritating? Not this happy camper. It lets everyone know dinner is ready (I normally make my rice last) and the smell of the rice more than makes up for the loud chime.There are 2 measuring cups and a spatula. These extra accessories are a plus and all fit inside the pan (inside the cooker) for storage.The pan is SUPER easy to clean. Even when I did one rice pot with no oil. It didnt stick to the pot. It's the only pot my kid (15 yr old) volunteers to wash. Oh, and I think its dishwasher safe.Could you work with one a little cheaper? Maybe, but I'm glad I didnt try and fail. This is my first rice cooker and hope it lasts a looong time.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'J. P.' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Love It!: I never had a rice cooker before.  I thought I prepared perfectly acceptable rice in a pan on the stove.  Oh sure, it might boil over sometimes and make a big mess and the rice might be soft one night and a little hard the next but rice is rice I thought.  But, I do love rice and someone suggested I might enjoy a rice cooker so I came to Amazon to do some research.  After reading dozens of customer reviews and agonizing about what size, whether no logic, fuzzy logic or neuro fuzzy logic would be best, and worry about which brand would be the most dependable, I finally decided on the "Zo" Zac-10 and after having it only a few days, I'm certain I made the right decision.  I found it very simple to operate although I agree the instruction booklet leaves a lot to be desired.  Plain old long grain white rice is tasty, light, fluffy and so much better than the rice I once prepared in a pan on the stove. I can't wait to try jambalaya, pilaf, risotto and puddings.  Do order the Ultimate Rice Cooker Cookbook.  It has some great recipes that will enhance your appreciation of the rice cooker and it's capabilities.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'William Bordeaux' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart CRC-400P1 4 Cup Rice Cooker, Stainless Steel Exterior'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Possibly the best investment for quick at home dinners: My girlfriend and I use this on a daily basis since purchase. It is perfect for serving 2-4 (4 Cup Rice Cooker). We also purchased TexMati Rice also available on amazon. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000EH4XYI/ref=oh_details_o02_s01_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1We don't have to stir the rice and we also use the included basket to cook veggies. No need for setting timers or watching your food closely.... simply press the button down and check back when convenient for you, when your rice completes it will be stored at ready to eat temp.Tips for using and cooking quick rice/veggies:Open lid and spray down with cooking sprayadd rice/water/butterinsert additional steaming colanderadd canned veggies/fresh veggies/seafood etc of choiceadd the lid to the toppress the buttonwait until unit switches from cook to warm.I only took off one star because the design of the colander could have been a bit better.. they could have added a handle or something to make it easier to dismount keep hot pads handy because obviously when it's been steaming for a few minutes it will be hot.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'JCo' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart WMR-CAP2 Round Classic Waffle Maker, Brushed Stainless,Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 29.95; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: Uneven heating: Given as a gift. Worth all the good reviews,  maybe I got a faulty one? First use - homemade batter and used a mixer. At first I thought I poured too much batter, bc it was wouldn't cook thru. The whole batch came out with mottled  areas of brown, tan, and white. I even flipped them to see if the heating was the issue.Round 2 this morning - I used a store bought batter, in case something i did the 1st time was wrong. I poured way less of the batter into the iron. This time, I increased the heat to 4. I checked and the top was still white. I turned it to 5. Still white. I decided to look at the bottom,  it was brown. So...uneven heating elements on top an bottom.  The rest of the batch, I just flipped halfway thru. Be sure to fit it back into the grooves when you flip it, or it won't close. Overall,  I thought this would be simply pouring in, closing, then presto - a perfect waffle. Not the case.

output: Really Unfortunate: I think I may have been sent a bootleg from amazon of this item-- no matter how much I wash my rice and troubleshoot using this device, the things I cook in this rice cooker including rice and instant pot recipes always boil over uncontrollably and make a mess all over my counter. instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Jennifer D' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Clean the metal filter screen with baking soda: I have seen comments in the reviews about juice spewing out of the sides of the machine and all over the counter.  This is not an issue with the machine.  This happens when the stainless steel screen filter gets clogged.  When my filter gets clogged, the same thing happens.  I tried everything to clean it.  I soaked it in hot water and lemon juice like the manual suggested,  I put it thru the dishwasher, etc.  Nothing worked.  I googled a solution and someone suggested scrubbing it with the nylon brush that comes with it and baking soda.  This works!  It makes your filter look brand new again.  Super easy and inexpensive fix!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'RevLani' to comment on the product 'BLACK+DECKER G48TD Waffle Maker, 3-in-1, Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 69.99; Brand: BLACK+DECKER; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS!: Black & Decker 3-in-1 waffle maker with reversible, removable grates lasted us exactly 3 years, with constant frustration. You would think this respected brand would never offer such a trashy product. The grates are the main problem – the clips do not hold them on correctly. While you are making your waffles, they come loose. Your waffles not only do not cook properly, but you also can't get the waffles grates back on the machine while they're hot. We tried to manually bend the clips to secure the grates, but that doesn't work either – this waffle maker simply ejects the grates. It's awful. We had a beautiful old-fashioned waffle maker that we received as a wedding gift that we enjoyed for decades, but it is no longer made. I just threw out this disgusting Black & Decker wafflemaker because I tried 1 last time to make it work today and the grate fell out on my hand!! Now I have a painful burn. I am furious. Please save yourself grief and do not even consider this piece of garbage.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'TunaMan' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart CRC-400P1 4 Cup Rice Cooker, Stainless Steel Exterior'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Overflows almost everytime: I got this for Xmas and began using it 4+ times a week.  The first thing noticed was that it overflowed onto the counter every time rice was cooked in 1-2 person sizes. The rice turned out very nice, but after cleaning the unit and counter about 20 times, we decided it would never see rice again.  Seems that a rice cooker shouldn't boil over to me. If we wanted that, we'd still be making rice on the stove top in a pan. We have a Zojirushi now.Ok, the Zojirushi, isn't a steamer, so the Cuisinart has become an egg and vegetable steamer.  Six refrigerated eggs in the steamer for 23 minutes and they are perfectly hard boiled.  For vegetables, just follow the times in the instruction booklet - they turn out very nice. No overflowing either, nice.2 stars since it is a very messy rice cooker.<update>Others comment that if I'd read other reviews and tips, then I'd not have the overflow problem. I shouldn't have to and someone considering a purchase should know this is a wildly seen problem. The device should be calibrated correctly, especially since it is a "rice cooker".We are still using it as a steamer. It works perfectly. It hasn't seen rice in 4+ years.

Another foot longer and I would have to rearrange the kitchen counter a bit less!A bigger beef is about the need to send the entire machine for changing the battery for the timer and memory. Even though it is a once in a 4-5 year hassle, shipping costs, replacement costs etc could and should have been avoided! Possibly easily!!Replacement items are expensive, at least the inner pan which costs ~50-60 dollars (Canadian); the inner lid and spatula etc are not expensive (not sure about shipping charges for those).The Canadian service and parts link is not clearly indicated in the manual. Writing to Zojirushi resulted in the following links:http://www.zojirushi.com/app/spare_parts/category/rice-cookers/NS-ZAC10/18,%20NS-ZCC10/18http://www.zojirushi.com/app/service_centers  (Canadian ones towards the bottom of the list of addresses)

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'C. Cooper' to comment on the product 'Waring Pro Professional Meat Grinder, Brushed Stainless Steel'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 320.0; Brand: Waring; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Food Grinders & Mills:Meat Grinders'.
output: Go no further. This is it.: Unless you are in business, you will find this grinder quite adequate.  I started grinding pork when I was 6 yrs old (really)with a large hand grinder.  As time has moved along, I have tried (through purchase or borrowing) several different home grinders.  I process 4-6 deer a year.  I have never been satisfied, until now.  This grinder has enough amps in the motor to process quickly.  I processed 3 deer recently.  I did not have to take the grinder apart to clear the stringy fascia even once.  Grinding was effortless. I like the forward and reverse switch mechanism for clearing jams.  Reverse automatically stops when you remove pressure.  Since I didn't have to actually use it, I can't tell you that it works great. All peices ahave a good fit. The stainless makes cleaning rather easy.  Truth in advertising wouldn't allow me to promote this as a Professional  grinder (which I have used), but I think that this grinder has found a home.  It's definitely worth the money.

output: Great Waffle Maker!  :): I can't believe that a traditional tool maker (B+D) turns out a great waffle maker! output: Good rice cooker, but can be messy: Works pretty well so far. The rice I have made with it has turned out well. I haven't yet used it for anything besides rice and grains though.One thing I will mention is that it is very important to thoroughly rinse your rice, because the starches will otherwise bubble up with the water and steam and create a huge mess. I usually rinse my rice 3 to 6 times, but with certain types of rice that wasn't enough to keep it from making a mess. With white rice it shouldn't be an issue though.It's also not very big, but it probably makes enough for 2 to 4 people. The small size wasn't a problem for me since I am usually just cooking for myself, but larger households might want to get a 6 or 8 cup one.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Valerie' to comment on the product 'Presto 04830 PowerPop Microwave Multi-Popper, Black'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 24.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Popcorn Poppers'.
output: My favorite popcorn popper!: I love this thing!  I had one for years, but eventually the lid broke and I couldn't pop corn without kernels popping right out of the top, so it was time to buy a new one.  The greatest advantage of  the popper is that you can pop with or without butter/oil. I find the popcorn from air poppers to be pretty dry. With this, I literally just add 4 drops of oil onto the unpopped kernels, swirl it around, and I love the result! But you don't have to add any, I'm pretty sure you could also add half a stick of butter and get good results as well.  For me the only downside is the need to keep buying the PowerCup concentrators. You can, however, make perfectly good popcorn without the concertrators, but you will end up with more unpopped kernels.

output: we love our zojirushi: well, so far i've only made white rice (basmati long grain) but it does it so well i'm happy. we got the smallest one and 2 cups feeds 2 people very well (enough for leftovers). i don't have a problem with any water leakage or overflowing. make sure you wash your rice very well. i let mine soak for 10 mins and then continuously rinse until i see the water is no longer as cloudy as before. if you're doing 1 cup of rice it's 1 cup water. 2 cups of rice? 2 cups of water. nothing fancy nothing extra, just press down the button and it does the job. so convenient and easy to use. cleanup is no problem.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'illiandantic' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: My Ducats, My Daughter (err, Rice): This is one of those devices (like the Musso 4080 Lussino Dessert Maker (i.e., an ice cream maker) here on Amazon) that you just can't believe anyone would spend that kind of money for, UNTIL you actually try it.  This "Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 5-1/2-Cup Neuro Fuzzy Rice Cooker and Warmer" simply transforms rice and elevates it to a higher plane of existence.  There's no way to compare rice cooked in a pot to what comes out of this rice maker.  We like rice.  We've been making it and eating it fairly regularly for years.  The same rice we used in a pot is entirely different (and delicious) when we cook it in this.  After seeing how good our normal rice was in this thing, we tried a batch of brown rice (I've hated brown rice since the dawn of time).  Even brown rice cooked in this rice maker comes out excellent.  Amazing.The downside, of course, is the price.  You just stare at it and go back and forth over whether or not plain-ol-rice is worth that amount of money.  Well, it is.  I rate this Zojirushi rice cooker at a Excellent 5 stars out of 5.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'BurgerBoy' to comment on the product 'Waring Pro Professional Meat Grinder, Brushed Stainless Steel'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 320.0; Brand: Waring; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Food Grinders & Mills:Meat Grinders'.
output: Simple and efficient: Bought the grinder as a replacement for the Kitchen Aid's grinder attachment, which puts metal shavings and motor grease into the meat.  This grinder works just as you would expect, with no compromises. A machine that does a single job and does it well; not a kitchen "gadget" with a dozen options you'll never use or a toy.  A little loud, but does the job without a lot of take-aparts and cleanings.I would have rated it five stars, but the plastic pusher was cracked on arrival, and had to be epoxied back together.  Compared to the beefy construction of the grinder, the thin plastic pusher seemed more like it was designed for some other (much cheaper) grinder. I wouldn't return the grinder for that, but as a package it was less than perfect as a result.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Brian Yim' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Classic style, modern functions: The classic white of this rice cooker is reminiscent of the 90s when virtually all rice cookers were made in white. The difference though, is that this unit has all the bells and whistles you need. It cooks a variety of rice perfectly and includes instructions to do so. Where it shines, though, is with cooking short-grain white rice  – the type most commonly found in Japanese and Korean cuisine. And, no wonder, Zojirushi is a Japanese brand.My tip: follow the instructions. There are two different cup sizes included. Fill your water up to the correct line. Choose the correct setting. If the instructions are followed, you'll be rewarded with a perfect bowl of rice, every time.Oh, and it plays a cute song when the rice is cooking. Oddly homey.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Angel H.' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Oh Ya!: I love this thing!  I was using a smaller less powerful juicer and decided that I needed something faster and that would reduce prep time.  I was spending a lot of time cutting my fruit and veggies just so I could get it into my old juicer.  To be fair, my other juicer worked fine and did what it was suppose to, it just wasn't efficient for my needs.I love Breville products and I had great expectations for this juicer.  I did my research and I knew what I features I was looking for.  I wanted something that had a powerful motor to grind through harder fruit and produce with out bogging the motor and I wanted a juicer that had a feed channel that would minimize my prep time.  I came across a few models and brands that seemed to fit the criteria, but my love for Breville products (based on experience and not marketing) made my decision simple.After learning more about the juicers that fit my criteria I really felt that buying a juicer that was all metal was in my best interest.  Aesthetically it fit my preference and taste and fit in with my current line-up of small kitchen appliances.  Materially, the stainless steel seemed a more durable option than the resin plastics of other brands.  Additionally, stainless steel in my opinion, is easier to sterilize and holds up well in the dishwasher and I don't have to worry about fading or cracking.Now on to the juicing.  I opened the box and to my expectation the juicer was packed well.  I came out of the box ready to use.  I cleaned the parts that would touch my juice as recommended.  I turned on the motor and was surprised at how quiet it was.  My smaller juicer sounded like a chainsaw in comparison, not to mention the motor on my smaller juicer was only 125w compared to the 1000w of the 800JEXL.  I expected that it would be louder just because of the motor size difference but again it was surprisingly quite.I juiced apples, carrots, celery, oranges, pears, beets, cucumber, kale, spinach and ginger to make my normal juice.  It took literally 5 minutes whereas my older juicer took about a half hour.  Prep of produce and fruit was easy as I did not need to cut anything.  It all fit right into the large feed tunnel - one of the key reasons I bought this juicer.  I noticed that I got more juice out of this juicer than my previous one.  I know now that is because of the motor and juicing mesh.  Because of the motor size combined with the mesh, the combination extracts more juice from the produce and fruit.  This ultimately saves me money in the long run although I am not able to quantify that at this point considering I have only been using it for a couple of weeks now.All-in-all, I HIGHLY recommend this juicer!  Breville is a GREAT brand and I am pleased with their quality and performance.  The description of the machine in the manufacturers marketing is as promised and it is understated in my opinion.  I appreciate quality and although this model may seem a bit high in price for some, I can only say you get what you pay for!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Snowbird' to comment on the product 'Presto Salad Shooter Electric Slicer/Shredder,White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Electric Utensils:Electric Slicers'.
output: Almost like the one my mom had when I was a kid.: So I actually bought this for shredding soap. My mom had a salad shooter when I was a kid back in the 80s. The plastic feels cheaper than the old one she had but I think that's just the way things are now. Sometimes I have soap loaves that don't turn out for whatever reason. Now I can cut it into pieces and shred the soap for confetti soap - mixing the shreds into another batch of cold process soap and mold it. The salad shooter makes quick work of it. One tip I will give though is don't let the shavings collect inside the cone. I was shaving into a storage bag and I kept getting clumps. Likely because all the shreds weren't falling out if the cone and they were sticking together. Disassembly is easy as I remember - take off the ring, pull out the blade and twist off the feed chute.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'David J. O'Connell' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Good juicer, with some idiocyncracies . . .: I was encouraged to begin juicing after watching a video "Fat, Sick, and Almost Dead," by Joe Cross.  I did my research and elected to replace my 10-year old Omega spinner, which was a pain to clean and inexplicably just stopped working as I began my juicing regime.  I looked a the arguments for centrifugal, like my old Omega, versus masticating juicers, like the venerable Champion.  In the end, I chose this Breville.Upon opening and assembly, it is truly an impressive beast.  It is large and stands tall on the counter, with a large vertrical feed tube, through which you insert the fruit and vegetables onto a spinning "Nutridisk," which is a combination grinder plate and screen/filter that rises off the disk at about 45 degrees, throwing the detritus as processed over to a good sized waste bucket.  Therein lies the first of its idiocyncracies.While processing the veggies and fruit, you have to be quick to insert the pusher, or bits of ground up stuff fly back at you and over the kitchen.  My wife, who is a cleaning fanatic, found this unacceptable.  But, with practice, and a quick two-handed feeding operation mastered, the problem is minimized.The second idiocyncracy is a problem that reading manual before use would have solved.  Without having done that, I am a guy after all, I started processing merrily and producing juice, but the arrangement of waste container which sets under, but not attached to the feeder cover, allows for waste bits to fly from between the bucket and the cover.  Another wifely correction forced reading of the manual, which recommends that you insert one of the bags you bring the veggies home with into the bucket, to make cleaning of the bucket easier.  Well, duh, taking the bucket to the composter and then bringing the bucket back to be washed every time was a bit of a pain; and, giving your clean-freak wife an easy victory on two fronts, humbling her man and avoiding cleaning another kitchen utensil were big pluses.The last set of idiocyncracies have to do with design.  Dip a toe into the juicing world and you confront kale, which I had always thought belonged in soup and was otherwise passed without notice in the veggie department. I like it in soup, but was unprepared for the pleasant earthy goodness it added to juices.  Along with its similar but unrelated buddy, broccoli raab or rapini, they have quickly become my most consumed green stuff.  But, this design grinds the stems and produces juice, with the leaves simply chopped into bits into the hopper. I am thinking of reserving the stems for juicing and the leaves for soup.  But, that is a story of another sort, for then I will have to compete with the aforementioned bride who just doesn't like to keep anything around long enough to show any signs of wilting.Another design difficulty has to do with economy of construction and user cleaning.  The housing over the Nutridisk is somehow spun or machined, leaving fine grooves on the inside.  While the machine is easy to clean on first blush, and is represented to be dishwasher safe, these grooves provide some difficulty.  When processing highly colored veggies, that color stays in those grooves, unless you are scrupulous about scrubbing them out.  Worse, if you just rinse the thing, which is a temptation if you are going to juice more than once a day, these grooves beging to show a distinct greenish color if not cleaned thoroughly.  Even the dishwasher fails to get this stuff out; it requires some elbow grease.A further design problem is the spout, which the advertising suggests a glass is enough to collect the juice.  There is a well built plastic pitcher which fits and collects the juice, but I advise you to immediately place a cup of some sort to collect the drips.  I use a quarter cup measure with a narrow base and wider top, which overlaps the wide base of the juicer engine unit.  A straight sided glass will not be wide enough to catch those last little drops.The design is a compromise, I understand.  Even with two speeds, one for soft stuff, like grapes and mango, and one faster one for harder stuff, like carrots, apples, and celery, there is a lot of waste.  Perhaps I will reinvest some time in the manual to see if I can reduce the loss. But, as one of the pluses, my second compost bin has filled very quickly.Other pluses are the introduction to other formerly ignored foodstuffs like ginger, because I didn't know what the hell to do with it unless it was Chinese stir fry; pears, because they went from hard as a rock to rotten in a nanosecond; beets, which I love roasted, but never were a big fave otherwise.Last, the Breville is not really good with soft stuff, like bananas, or citrus. One must have other devices which are better at juicing those things.  But, as a follower of Alton Brown, I had hoped for a fully multi-tasking device, but hope springs eternal and sometimes leads to disappointment.[ADDED COMMENT: 2/28/14] A WARNING: Do NOT put the juice jug in the dishwasher, especially the bottom basket where the heat is greater.  In a surprise, following the advice that all the parts were machine washable, I rinsed and placed the jug in the dishwasher several times.  The jug appears to be of durable and thick plastic; but, to my disappointment, the heat of the dishwasher warped the top lip and cover of the jug.Amazon does not have replacements; you must contact Breville directly.  At $16.00 a pop, they are not overly expensive; but, I would have liked to have avoided the warping/melting with a product warning.David O'Connell

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'AJ' to comment on the product 'Presto 04821 Orville Redenbacher's Hot Air Popper, 1 Liters, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 39.61; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Popcorn Poppers'.
output: Simple design lacks any common sense safety mechanism: This simple air popper design is reminiscent of the air popper I used while growing up. I didn’t think to look for any specific options when purchasing it, but it lacks some common sense safety features. There is no on/off switch nor timer. It is turned on by plugging it into the wall, and turned off by unplugging it from the wall. In a short time, it has enough heat output to all but destroy itself.It is marketed as leaving “virtually no un-popped kernels”, so it is tempting to leave it running to try to get those last few kernels to pop. DON’T DO IT! On the first use, with Orville Redenbacher original popcorn kernels, I expected unpopped kernel count to be low. There were still several kernels bouncing around, so I let it run a little longer before unplugging it. Not many remaining kernels did pop, but the extra duration was sufficient to slightly deform the clear plastic top and melt the bottom of the plastic butter tray enough to cause it to stick to the rest of the lid. The air popper (from another manufacturer) I used as a child had a metal butter tray and is still functioning. I don’t expect the same longevity out of this unit and I would exercise extreme caution using this around children. This gets HOT and you certainly wouldn’t want kids fumbling around on a counter trying to unplug it from the wall. Otherwise, it is relatively inexpensive and functional albeit simple. If I had to purchase another, I would look for alternatives.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'R. Silvester' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Excellent appliance that lives up to the hype: I spent months shopping for this rice cooker, going back and forth between cheaper and more expensive rice cookers. Having once lived in Japan over 4 years, it isn't "just a rice cooker" as my wife purports, so I decided on a Zoji in the end. My only initial hesistation was the inbility to replace the battery in the LCD display.  However, the ability to cook brown rice just as well as other rice and its record for reliability outweighed the battery issue. I've had the NS-ZCC10 for two months, using it 2-3 times a week, and have been very pleased with the results. And the concern that it would not make enough for a family of five has been no issue as I seldom have the need to make more than 3 cups for a single meal. (In Japan its typical to have a batch of rice cooked up to eat throughout the day, however, I only use it for single meals) Cleanup is super simple compared to the aluminum single button Hitachi I had for 20 years (it was broken by the movers- maybe it should have broken sooner).

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'DeAnne' to comment on the product 'Presto 06003 Options Electric Multi-Cooker/Steamer'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 40.78; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Steamers'.
output: Great Blanching Pot for Canning: Had an older version of this Presto pot for 30 years that I used to blanch peaches for canning. I set mine up next to the sink with cold water, which freed up space on the stove and streamlined the canning process. Highly recommend.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Candy' to comment on the product 'Presto 05450 DualDaddy Electric Deep Fryer, Black'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 44.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Fryers:Deep Fryers'.
output: Makes awesome wings!: We got this deep fryer to make homemade chicken wings, and we love it so far! Still on our first batch of oil; we’re using peanut at the moment, but I purchased this style of deep fryer because I plan on making tallow to use in the future. Tallow solidifies at room temperature, so I needed a deep fryer that didn’t have a submersible heating element. I believe others have said that the oil temp can get too hot, but personally I don’t think I’ve seen it go over 375 degrees. That’s the exact temperature I wanted to cook wings in anyways, so it works well for us! Maybe if you let it preheat too long the temperature will go up higher? Not sure on that though.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Sweetsuzie' to comment on the product 'Aroma Housewares ASP-137 Grillet 3Qt. 3-in-1 Cool-Touch Electric Indoor Grill Portable, Dishwasher Safe, 3-Quart, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 31.1; Brand: Aroma Housewares; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Indoor Grills & Griddles:Electric Grills'.
output: Best Ever Easy Go-to Pot with easy clean up!: I have had my little Aroma Pot for several months now and it is absolutely my hands down favorite little kitchen pot!  I call it my go-to pan.  Whether I am just heating up things, grilling a few sandwiches, cooking burgers etc it is the very easiest to use.  What makes this pan so special is the ultra easy clean up.  Just a paper towel will wipe it clean!  No sticking or need to soak like some of my other grill pans require.  This is not a crock pot or pretends to be.... but a counter cooker with a simple way to cook or  grill inside with ease.  It has a warm setting that allows you to cook something and turn the thermostat down to warm until you are ready to eat.  This is a wonderful little pot if you have young children..... for you can quickly heat up something in the pan without turning on the oven.  I just love my little Aroma Pot!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Sharon L Miner' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart Food Processor, Mini-Prep 3 Cup, 24 oz, Brushed Chrome and Nickel, DLC-2ABC'. No more than 20 words. output: This mini food processor is great for so many food prep tasks: This mini processor makes short work of finely chopping pecans and other nuts. I bake cookies during the two weeks before Christmas each year and make up cooky boxes for friends and relatives. Finely chopping nuts is so easy with this appliance. Russian teacakes turn out wonderfully with finely chopped nuts and so do other cookies and coarse chopping is possible too (for fruitcake ? and biscotti). The processor has 2 settings, chop and grind. I highly recommend this appliance for making chopped onion for tuna salad and you will find other uses for this appliance. The bowl, blade assembly and lid are easy to clean with dish soap and hot water (just be careful when washing the blade, it is very sharp). I am sure this mini processor will become one of your favorite appliances.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'D 5253' to comment on the product 'BLACK+DECKER G48TD Waffle Maker, 3-in-1, Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 69.99; Brand: BLACK+DECKER; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: Sadly, not the quality B&D has been known for.: I didn't read any other reviews with this problem, so it's hard to say if we just got a lemon unit or others haven't actually used the waffle plates.We were sooo anxious to make waffles, but....  Right out of the box, the coating was coming off edges of the waffle plates.  Prepped it for use anyway (thinking I could overlook that minor part), turned the unit on and closed it to heat.  The bottom waffle plate immedately popped out of the security tab in the front.  Turned off the unit, unplugged it, and once it cooled, I rotated the plates thinking that might help.  But this time, the bottom plate popped out of the tab and then the top plate popped out.  When the top plate pops out, it falls.  Dangerous if it had been hot!  Upon VERY close inspection, it seems that the drip spout of the waffle pieces are off or missized just enough to keep them from "fitting" together when in use and therefore, causing one or both plates to pop out of the front tab.  I did not reverse them to see if the same thing happened with the griddle sides.Not only useless if the plates don't stay in place, but dangerous if the unit is hot when they pop out.  AND messy if the plate happens to have batter on it when it pops out.

output: Fantastic as "hot pot": I'll update this later if anything goes awry with the pot, but so far, it's AWESOME!!!  I purchased this specifically to use as a "hot pot" (Asian fondue, if you will) and it's great.  It gets super hot, super fast, and cools down just as quickly. Otherwise, it's great.  Since I've only used it for hot pot, I haven't tested out just cooking meat directly on it, etc... but, it's been great for the purpose I purchased it for... super excited to use it!  And it cleans up easily with a simple sponge/soap.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Trinichick0114' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Love It: After many years of making horrible rice on the stovetop, hit or miss EVERY TIME and mostly miss, not to mention the spill over the second I blink, I recently discovered how to make decent rice in a pressure cooker (Wolfgang Puck 5 Quart). The rice came out great but the pressure cooker was too bulky, cumbersome, too many parts and pieces to clean, and took up a lot of counter space. I wanted something smaller that I can leave on the countertop and still make good rice. I also have one of the cheaper rice cookers/steamer with the glass lid and a simple "on" button. Maybe I used it incorrectly but I didn't like the texture or flavor of the rice it made. It also took too much guess work on how much water I needed to use per cup of rice. I hate guesswork after a long day and being hungry so that rice cooker sat in my cupboard for about 3 years. Anyway, onto the Zojirushi rice cooker. After MUCH reading I decided this would be perfect for me since just about everyone says it makes perfect rice every time. Yes, it is pricey but I prefer to invest in great products that get good use rather than waste money on something that will sit in my cupboard collecting dust. But that's just me. I received the rice cooker on the estimated delivery date, and I used it the very second it arrived. It doesn't take up much more counter space than maybe a four slice toaster. It comes with a spatula, spatula holder which clips on either the right or left side of the rice cooker, the inner bowl with easy to see/read water markers/measurements, two rice measuring cups (one for white rice, and one for brown rice), and an instruction booklet that includes a few recipes. It has a handle which makes for easy transfer from countertop to dinner table or anywhere you want it, and it even has a retractable cord which I thought was fantastic (one less thing to lose or figure out what it belongs to). The cover pops up and closes rather smoothly. The buttons are nice and easy to read, and pretty straightforward. As for ease of use, it is wonderful at least for making simple white rice since that was all I used it for straight out of the box WITHOUT reading instructions and I saw it demonstrated on Youtube a bazillion times. I rinsed three cups of jazmin rice, put it in the inner bowl, poured water in up to the three cup line for white rice (note: water measurements are different for brown rice), gave it a swirl so the rice was even, pressed the menu button to white rice/harder setting, then the cooking/reheat button. It played a tune to let me know it started and I walked away. That was it. I left it unattended while I did other things and didn’t notice when it was done which, for me, was a good thing since I wanted to know how it kept the rice in such a case since I’m always multi-tasking. It automatically switches to keep warm mode. I’d say I left it for about 40-45 mins so I’m not quite sure how long it took exactly for the rice to complete cooking BUT the good thing was the rice did not have any burn marks at the bottom. It was fluffy and moist but not wet. It was perfect rice.  I even smelled the difference in the rice, and it tasted great. The texture, consistency, and stickiness were just right for my liking. My hubby gets home from work hours after I do so I kept it in the keep warm mode for only 2 hrs fearing it would dry out but when he got home 3 hrs later the rice was just as good as when it was just done. A bit more wetness from the steam trapped inside but it didn’t affect the rice in any way after a quick stir. Also, the bowl sits snug in the cooker so when you stir it doesn’t swirl around all pointless. Well, I only got the cooker yesterday and I was only able to use it once for one type of rice so I hope this helps for those of you who are more concerned about plain white rice like I was. I still have leftover rice in the cooker so I cannot comment on the ease of clean up but there are only two things to clean, the non-stick bowl (should be a breeze), and the inner lid gasket which looks like it can be wiped/rinsed clean. The spatula can be tossed in the dishwasher/hand washed. The main part itself can be wiped down with a damp cloth but it made absolutely zero mess/spills when I used it so I don’t even need to do that. As I use the other functions I will update. My one and only concern and reason for 3 stars is the battery. I’ve read that it should last approx. 4-5 yrs and can only be replaced by the company. I do not have the time or money to spend on something that should be so simple. That, to me, is the only flaw in the making of this product. Being the DIY person that I am, if the battery does fail I will be opening it myself to fix it. Also, the clock stays on even when unplugged which uses up battery life. Some people may like that feature but it wastes battery life making for quicker replacement.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Catsm' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Very disappointing: We bought this because we wanted to juice some of our enormous crop of apples to make wine.  We have an old Acme juicer that belonged to my parents that works well, but the chute is small, and the basket needs to be emptied often.  We liked the fact that the Breville's chute is large enough to minimize or even eliminate cutting the fruit and that the pulp is ejected which would also save time when juicing large quantities.  While its design reduces the need to cut up the fruit, I have to say that the quality and quantity of juice is very inferior compared to my the old Acme, and it was not at all time-saving because of the extra time to clean and the waste involved.  We had to allow the juice to sit overnight in the refrigerator in order to settle and then siphoned it for a clearer product due to the very large amount of foam generated (2" of juice with the remainder foam in the pitcher), and the juice contained pulp too, not clear at all, despite cleaning the basket after every pitcher.  The extricated pulp was moist and contained CHUNKS of fruit in it.  The third session before any fruit was introduced to it, the motor noticeably sped up and slowed down.  We packed it up and returned it.  We would not recommend this juicer.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'D. Saverino' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart CRC-400P1 4 Cup Rice Cooker, Stainless Steel Exterior'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Cooks rice well... but a mess is included: While this rice cooker is useful in cooking rice to the correct consistency, it also suffers a design flaw: when I add one cup of rice and two cups of water (far less than the suggested capacity of the machine), it spits hot starchy water out of the steam-hole and all around the periphery of the lid towards the end of the cooking process. I put a cutting board underneath and place it well in the centre of the counter when I use it so that it won't spray the hot, starchy water onto the floor, cupboards... or most importantly, that it won't spray hot water on me! With the liquid overflow during each use, it also takes quite a bit of clean-up afterwards. This is the only rice cooker I have ever owned, so I don't know if they all have this same messy flaw in design, or if it only this particular model. If you buy this item, you should also pick up some stainless steel cleaner and countertop cleaner, since you will also be using a good deal of these products with each use.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Tara' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart Fondue Pot, 3 Quart, For Chocolate, Cheese, Broth, Oil, Stainless Steel, CFO-3SSP1'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 63.08; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Electric Fondue Pots'.
output: Great fondue pot: SOOO fun! This is a quality fondue maker and is a great Dinner party option.  Brings me back to my childhood dinners with my family and can't wait to share with my child. We did a traditional fondue and cooked steak, tuna, turkey, pork & a ton of veggies in vege oil last night and had a blast. We had a ton of different sauces to dip in and ate for hours. This fondue pot get hot enough and works perfect. Very sleek and pretty too. And big enough pot for everyone to be cooking at once. Mushrooms in oil rock. Your don't even need a dipping sauce. Haven't tried a cheese of chocolate fondue in this pot yet but that is not how I was brought up eating it so I doubt I will do much of that anyway. The oil is great!! instruction: Please simulate consumer 'William R' to comment on the product 'Presto 04821 Orville Redenbacher's Hot Air Popper, 1 Liters, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 39.61; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Popcorn Poppers'.
output: Shuts off from overrheating and burns the popcorn.: I finally decided to throw my Presto Orville Reddenbacher air popper away today. I would never take this unit to a thrift store to get rid of it, because someone else would buy it and realize later they threw their money away. I rarely get one batch of popcorn out of it. Most of the time it overheats half-way through the cycle and stops. The heat inside then burns the popcorn sitting in the unit, setting off the smoke alarm (see the picture for the result of my attempted batch today.) I have never been able to get two batches out of it, and rarely one. I fill the cup exactly to the top and follow the instructions exactly. There's nothing you can mess up. The machine is poorly desgned, in my opinion, and the heater inside gets way too hot and trips the built-in emergency shutoff thermostat. It has to sit about 15 minutes to cool down enough to restart, and then it just burns the next batch. I would never recommend this unit to anyone.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Donald K. Todd' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart CRC-400P1 4 Cup Rice Cooker, Stainless Steel Exterior'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Rice cooker - Simple and works: This cooker has reduced rice and other grain cooking to the essentials.  The unit power is controlled by plugging and unplugging the device at the wall.  If you leave it plugged (on warm) in for a long time after the rice cooks it will eventually dry the rice completely.Follow the ratios of water to grain recommended in the accompanying booklet, not on the grain packages.  I've successfully cooked rice, grits and oatmeal.  Haven't tried cream of wheat yet.  The steamer basket placed over the cooking rice turns out veggies that are perfectly steamed when cooking a couple of servings of rice.  However, if cooking a larger batch of rice, I suspect the veggies would be overcooked.

output: I love the size of this pint sized bag: I ordered several sizes of bags to use with my new Foodsaver. I love the size of this pint sized bag. I'm only starting to use them, but they are a perfect size for just my husband and I. I put approx. 2 cups of sweet corn (after blanching and cutting off the cob) in each bag. If you are freezing for 2-3 people/portions, this seems to be a great size bag. After my bags of corn were frozen, I tried one out: I placed the frozen bag flat in the microwave and cut a slit in the top side. I microwaved a few minutes and it worked perfect. I poured out the contents in a bowl and stirred in a little salt and butter. I will be ordering more of this size. (I had tried the Foodsaver steamer bags initially, but could not get all the air out...so I ended up finishing the rest of my corn with these bags.)

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Gregg Hinkle' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Cooks Perfectly, but takes longer than expected: I have cooked steel cut oats, rolled oats, wild rice, jasmine rice and long grain rice in this rice cooker so far. Everything I cooked has turned out perfectly, so you may ask why only 4 stars? There are a few reasons. First of all, it takes a long time to cook. I cooked steel cut oats and it took 45 minutes. I cooked wild rice and it are over an hour. Even jasmine rice takes about 40 min. The pre-determined measuring lines for rice (white or brown) is only if you are using short or medium grain. I typically use long grain. The default porridge amounts is not what you used if you are cooking oats. On their website, they do have instructions on how to cook all of these other options, but it is not easy to find. Maybe in Japan where this rice cooker is made most people use short or medium grain rice, but this is not the case where I live. It would be nice to have long grain white and brown rice as an automatic setting instead of having to find what is the proper water to rice ratio and setting for this particular rice cooker which is buried somewhere in their website. The results are perfect, but figuring out how to get there and the time it takes to get there can be annoying.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Jim Krupnik' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi EJ-PC50 Gourmet Food Steamer'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 189.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Steamers'.
output: OK, I have not tried rice yet, but...: For the price, and for the ease of cleanup alone, this steamer is fabulous. I have used the "fan" inserts for pots over the last 200 years (so it seems), and bought this steamer as part of my ongoing effort to build the ultimate kitchen in the small space that I now have availabe. I figured that a plug in appliance like this would free up a burner for a real pot.Wow! So far, I have used it for broccolli, asparagus, carrots, green beans, eggs, and fish. It is so far ahead of the pot inserts in terms of speed and quality of the finished product, that the two do not even remotely compare. One reviewer had a problem with brown rice. I have not tried to cook brown rice with it yet, but I know that rice needs a lot of water. This may not be the best machine for brown rice. A dedicated rice cooker might be the answer here. On the other hand, if you want PERFECTLY steamed veggies of any variety, even two or three at a time, and want them done to order with a bell to indicate that it's time to serve them, buy this gem of a machine.Cleanup is a dishwasher snap, and for those who worry about draining vitamin content from their cooked greens, a full stack of produce yields only a few ounces of condensate in the pop out drip tray. There may be better out there, but until I see it in action, this gem has my vote.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Abyisheik' to comment on the product 'Presto 02970 Professional SaladShooter Electric Slicer/Shredder, Black,1 count'. No more than 20 words. It would come with just the presto box with addresses stamped on top of the box.Will update after I try with the step down transformer.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Neil Walters' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. output: Like most juicers there is lots of cleaning: The Elite 800 is well built has a great motor and is extremely efficient at juicing.  It is attractive on the counter.  The juice remains cool.  The pitcher is a good size and is designed to separate the foam if that is what you desire.  The pulp is relatively dry so most of the juice seems to be in the pitcher. We are now use to the processes and overall it is an excellent juicer.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Pghmom' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Love this juicer and I use it... a lot!: I rec'd this juicer as a gift, so you won't see me as a verified buyer.  However, I had been looking at juicers for at least 6 months. My friend told me that Brevilles were the best juicers as far as ease of cleaning, and that a lot of people get hung up on cleaning them.  I think my aunt decided on this one very randomly, but it is exactly what I wanted.  I follow the directions and rinse/wash the pieces immediately after juicing and I do not have any problems keeping it clean and functional.  It really only has a few parts that need cleaning.  But I am using it at least 5 times per week (it has been 3 months) and I love it.  I started with straight carrots and one apple.  I am now into mixing all kinds of veggies and fruits.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Toby' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Loud and blows juice everywhere: So the first couple times I used this juicer I liked it, other than it was loud and very time consuming to clean.  After the 2nd time using it I noticed it starting to blow juice out of  where the pulp container and top lid meet.  All parts were hand washed and the included brush was used to clean the mesh as the instructions stated to do.  However each time it was used the pulp which was getting wetter and wetter.  It was blowing probably a half a cup of juice over my countertops and under my wall cabinets.  Going to return this and try a masticating juicer.  I'm sure it will be slower but hopefully not as noisy and I won't have to spend an hour cleaning up everywhere it blows juice.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Ben A. Phillips' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Other positive reviews are true: Fantastic.  You should note that if you prefer white rice, $200 for a rice cooker might not be necessary.  What I really like about this is how well it does brown rice.  It's not actually that simple to do brown rice correctly, or at least quick.  I previously had a cheapo rice cooker that generally scalded the bottom and would leave some hard rice kernels when it did brown rice.If you don't dislike the taste, you're doing yourself a pretty big and simple favor eating brown rice.And anyone complaining about Twinkle Twinkle Little Star is silly.  Or perhaps not silly enough.  It's so Japanese, it's quite amusing to hear a gawdy song play announcing the arrival of "tasty rice!"
