instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Pen Name1' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: 2nd one in a row, doesn’t even turn on!?: I registered for this juicer on my wedding registry and received it. I tried using it for the first time a few months after we moved out of our tiny studio apartment and into a real kitchen where I had room to actually unpack and make space to juice. It did not even turn on. The motor sounded like it was trying to run but wouldn’t run at all. The customer service woman gave me such attitude about why I hadn’t tried using it sooner and finally agreed to let me return it and ship me a replacement. I became pregnant and was afraid to juice anything during my pregnancy and finally decided to try that new, replacement juicer tonight. I bought, washed and cut up all sorts of fruits and veggies and went to start the new juicer and the EXACT same thing happened. It won’t work. I tried troubleshooting too the first time with a rep and this time by searching and remembering what we did the first time. They don’t want to let me exchange it. What an absolute waste of time, money, space and an even bigger disappointment!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Jeffd' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart CRC-400P1 4 Cup Rice Cooker, Stainless Steel Exterior'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Cuisinart vs Hamilton Beach rice cooker: I bought both the Cuisinart and the Hamilton Beach (cheaper).  Cooked rice in both of them to compare.  The Cuisinart cooked a cup of rice in about 15 minutes.  The Hamilton Beach in about 30 minutes.  I believe due to the hotter cooking temperature of the Cuisinart, water boils more violently thus cause the steam to splatter (Cuisinart has a direct glass lid which has a hole in it for steam to escape, but when there were too much steam, the hole could not handle and cause steam to escape everywhere.  The Hamilton Beach has a locked lid, so steam would be channeled to the capturing cup on the side instead of splattering around the lid.Each model has its own advantages.  The Cuisinart has a see-through glass lid which, has a nicer stainless steel chassis, a simple Cook or Heat latch, and cooks faster.  The Hamilton Beach has a locked lid so steam doesn't splatter, comes with 5 control modes (white rice, whole grain, Hot Cereal, Steam, Warm) and a time-display window.  The keep warm feature on both are too warm, so they share the same disadvantage.My wife decided to keep them both.  The Hamilton will be used mainly for cooking rice, while the Cuisinart will be used for cooking other dishes (vegetables,..) since she can see what going on thru the glass lid.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'BlocParty' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Compact Juicer, Silver, BJE200XL, 10" x 10.5" x 16"'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 138.07; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: Get it and juice and be healthy.: This is my favorite juicer. I’ve used quite a few juicers in the past. One thing I learned that I wanted was the ability to put fruits in without cutting them down to smaller sizes. Check. Second I wanted it to have a strong enough motor and sharp enough blades so the fruits aren’t a struggle to juice. Check. Finally I wanted the trash to be trash and not filled with juice still. Check.I bought this in 2017 and was happy. Then it broke during a move and I purchased the newer version (that does not look like this one at all). It was the worst! While it took whole fruits, it could barely juice a grape without struggling. I returned it and waited a few weeks to see this one drop in price. I purchased it again and have been happy ever since.Newer is definitely not always better.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Prism' to comment on the product 'Presto 05420 FryDaddy Electric Deep Fryer,Black'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 37.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Fryers:Deep Fryers'.
output: Doesn't regulate temperature, Bad chicken.: This product says it "regulates temperature" without having to do anything. There's no controls on it. It didn't regulate when I tried frying chicken in it. It got WAY too hot and the chicken wasn't up to temp on the inside, but was fried dark on the outside. It would have been near raw on the inside, and unsafe to eat. My fry thermometer clocked the oil at 385F (with a max of 400F on the thermometer) before I just turned it off. Get something that lets YOU control the temperature.Waste of money.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'David' to comment on the product 'Emerson 0.7 CU. FT. 700 Watt, Touch Control, Black Microwave Oven, MW7302B'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 71.31; Brand: Emerson; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Microwave Ovens:Countertop Microwave Ovens'.
output: Won't last more than a year: Anyone who gives this product a great review just hasn't owned it long enough. The wattage is really low which means you have to almost double most directions on frozen food, etc. In addition to being a hassle, this means food isn't cooked the way it should be and items are often rubbery or not the intended consistency. After several months of mediocrity, it breaks down. Still lights up and makes noise like it's working, but has ZERO heating capacity. It's cheap but not worth it. Spend the extra twenty bucks and get something that will last more than a year.

output: Great juicer!: I really like this juicer so far and am a big fan of Breville equipment. I saw a few complaints about splatter. Mine didn’t as long as I used properly (pitcher lined up and used the tool to push the fruit/veg down the chute). My only complaint is having to trim peel off citrus first, but otherwise is great. I have done citrus, carrots, celery, ginger and spinach so far with great results and the volume it produces is exceptional. The leftover pulp is almost dry to the touch!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Shelly420' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: This really is an excellent juicer: This is the 2nd juicer I've owned, and it's my favorite of the two.  It sounds like a jet engine when you turn it on.  I love hearing it, but if you're wanting to make something while everyone else is sleeping nearby, you're going to wake them up.  This one is very easy to clean & doesn't make a huge mess like the Juiceman one I ended up returning to Costco before I bought this one.  I also love that it has a large opening in the top so if your apples & pears aren't too big, you don't have to bother cutting them up.  I go through phases, some months I'll make juice every day, then I get sick of cleaning it and stop for awhile.  Sooner than later though, I stop feeling all the benefits of the juices, so I end up pulling it right back out & starting up again.  Yeah, I complain about cleaning it, but as far as juicers go, this one is easy to clean.  I very highly recommend this, but just plan on it taking a good 20 minutes minimum (if you're super fast) to 30 minutes if you don't move fast in the morning like me) from start to finish.  I always clean it immediately, otherwise it's 10 times harder after the gunk has dried on it (you only make that mistake once).

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'David M. Fishlow' to comment on the product 'BLACK+DECKER G48TD Waffle Maker, 3-in-1, Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 69.99; Brand: BLACK+DECKER; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: Ooops! Don't!: Bought one on impulse without checking around and assumed in error it would work as a sandwich press. . Flimsy,  light-weight construction. Tiny springs intended to hold grill plates in place require constant adjustment and will probably snap right off before long. Plates easily slip out even when hot: dangerous! No ribbed grill plate: flat griddle not nearly as useful as a cast-iron skillet on the stove. Useless for panini; top too light and flimsy to use as a press; hinges non-expandable so forget about a good baguette-sandwich. Grease spouts at corners drain right onto the counter, requiring an improvised "catcher" cup shallow enough to fit below. Feels "tinny" and is. Plates easy (too easy!) to remove and wash; problem is getting them to stay put when you put them back.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'R. Stone' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart CRC-400P1 4 Cup Rice Cooker, Stainless Steel Exterior'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 49.99; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Good rice cooker except for the boil-over problem.: For the most part, this is a good rice cooker. I have had one for six years, and the teflon is holding up very well. I only use the plastic spatula that came with it, or wooden spoons, to scoop the rice out. Other than that, I make sure to not store anything inside it but the vegetable steamer, and I don't use abrasive scrubbies to clean it. As others point out, it makes a mess on the countertop because the rim has bumps on it which don't allow the lid to sit tightly on top. There are other rice cookers out there that don't do that, so there is no reason to put up with that flaw, but if you do want to get this model, I solved the boil-over problem by replacing the lid with a silicone boil-over safeguard, available here on Amazon. And you can also use the safeguard on your spaghetti pot or anything else that tends to boil over!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'MHS' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: An entirely different class of appliance than Americans are used to.: Where has this rice cooker been all of my life and why didn't I get one sooner?It has a retractable cord. It has a carrying handle. The clock stays set and functional even when the unit is not plugged in. It plays twinkle twinkle little star when I start my rice, and Amaryllis when it is done cooking my rice. It keeps the rice warm for hours, and even gives you a display telling you exactly how long the rice has been kept warm for.  It has an alarm mode, so you can awaken to freshly cooked rice after setting up the rice cooker the night before.It does not make a crusty skin along the bottom of the pan either. There is  only just the slightest hint of the skin that forms.Cleanup is a breeze, involving using the paddle to scoop away any excess rice, then a brief rinse in water and 10 seconds of gentle sponging down (Don't scrub! you'll damage the non stick coating, and there is no need for abrasives at all.)

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Paul' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Was intimidated using auto-cookers but it doesn't get easier than this.: So I actually have an aversion to auto-cookers simply because I always feel like I will push the wrong button and the thing either bursts into flames or the food comes out charred or raw. I doubt I'd ever use an air fryer or pressure cooker but this thing is so slick and easy, I love it.Instructions are simple to follow for cooking basic rice and once you get comfortable with the settings, you can mix it up and add ingredients before cooking. I started with basic white sticky rice, about 50min to cook. Then I added some furikake (rice seasoning). Still awesome. Then I went into mexican style rice with tomato sauce, cumin, garlic powder, chicken bullion and tomato bullion. I failed the first time. came out crunchy when following the instructions for the water-to-rice ratio. But then I just went with a 1.5-to-1 water to rice and it came out awesome! And the timer is super accurate. I set it to be ready at 6pm (or 1800 hours since its only setting is 24hour clock), and it was done within about 2 minutes of the time.Point is, don't feel too bad if you're anxious around complicated cooking appliances. I still don't use any other button on a microwave besides the numbers for a nuking time. But if I could get the hang of this thing, then anyone can. :)P.S. You can cook other things in a rice cooker besides rice. It's basically a low temperature steamer. I'll try veggies later. Kinda wondering if i can bake a cake in it now. I'll experiment a little and see what happens.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'J L.' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Life Can Be Good (Sometimes): My Zujirushi rice cooker arrived today, and I made my first batch of rice in it!  The machine is easy to set up and use.  I watched YouTube videos and read a lot of reviews before purchasing, so that gave me a leg up so to speak.Somehow I expected it to be a much heavier appliance than it is.  It is quite lightweight.  Everything so far seems to function as it should.  DO READ ALL OF THE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST, as did I, though, so you do not make any errors.After washing and drying the inner bowl, the rice paddle, and the removable lid, I used my rice washing bowl to wash two cups of Jasmine rice.  I never prepared Jasmine rice before in my life, although I am sure it must be the same rice I have eaten in Chinese and Thai restaurants many times.  It is at best a medium grain rice and much more sticky than the rice I usually eat, i.e. parboiled long grain rice.  Cooking the rice was a  breeze.  I put two cups of washed Jasmine rice in the inner bowl and added 2.5 cups of distilled water.  I set it for white rice and "soft."  It took about 50 minutes to cook it which was fine with me as I had plenty of other things to do.  It turned out nicely, and I am going to use the leftovers to make fried rice, which I think I shall enjoy more.I used the Jasmine rice today as a base over which I spooned some tinned soup.  It is purely a matter of personal tase, but I much prefer my long grain parboiled rice over this Jasmine rice, at least for the types of meals I usually make, e.g. soups, creoles, seafood gumbo, as a side to veggie burgers, etc.  I just think the long grain parboiled rice is the most satisfying.  I suppose it may have something to do with how one was raised and how one has lived for most of one's life.Clean up was a breeze.  Set up and first use were easy (I read everything and read reviews and watched YouTube videos, so it did not seem like much of a challenge to first set up and use it).  I love the little tune played at the start and the end!  I HATE buzzers on microwaves and spin dryers, etc.  Why cannot they all use some little bit of music like this rice cooker uses?  It is so cheerful, and it does not make one jump out of one's skin to hear it.  Anyone who does not like the little tunes played at the start and the finish of a cooking cycle must be an old Grinch.I plan to make one cup of my parboiled rice in this rice cooker just to see how it turns out.  I will rinse it well first and keep an eye on it.  I hope it turns out well because I definitely like it more than the Jasmine rice.  I also like brown rice and plan to try it.  I love wild rice, too, but I am not sure if this rice cooker cooks wild rice.  Japanese must eat mainly sushi rice and brown rices because this rice cooker seems more geared to those rices than any others.I plan to make some steel cut oats later in the week.  I think they will turn out well, too, based on my experience today so far.  I love that I all I have to do is put the washed rice into the machine with the appropriate amount of water, set it, and walk off without having to remember to do anything else.  I have seen several YouTube videos where veggies and even some meats were added to the rice with great results, so I plan to try that soon, too.  One YouTube chef added a tomato and a splash of olive oil to his rice, and it turned out beautifully.  I bet it tasted good.  I want to try that as well.  My only concern is whether the acid in the tomato might not be good for the non-stick coating.  Manufacturer warns against using vinegar but does not mention tomatoes.The upshot is that my first batch of rice was easy to make and turned out fine.  I must try more rices and porridge in it as well, but if all goes well, and especially if I can get away with making parboiled, or even plain long grain rice in this cooker, I shall be happy.  I have no problems making consistently good rice on the stove top, but I have to watch my stove top rice and turn it off at the end cooking time, etc.  This rice cooker can free me up not to have stick close to the stove top.If you love rice and eat a lot of it, as do I, then this might be a good purchase for you.  If you only eat rice once per week or less, then you can probably stick with the stove top method and earmark the $200 for something else you want/need.As something of an aside, I found a couple of etsy sellers who custom make cozy covers for appliances and teapots, etc.  I probably will have a cozy made for this rice cooker as it will live its life on my countertop (no cupboard space available), and I want to keep it protected from dust, etc.Re the timer function, I have not tried it so far, and I probably will rarely need to use it, but it is a very nice feature to have.  For example, if you knew you were going to be away from home all day or all afternoon at least, then you could use the timer to have rice ready at 6 or 7 p.m. or whatever time you will be back home.  The timer would also be nice if you wanted your rice to start cooking say one hour before you arise from a nap or come in from working in the garden, etc.  Many reviewers lament the long cooking times, but really, the cooking times are not so long.  It takes 40 minutes to cook long grain parboiled rice on the stove top.  It did not take much longer to make Jasmine rice in this rice cooker.  Besides, you should plan ahead.  If I know I want to eat a meal at say noon, then I wash the rice and start it cooking up to two hours before I plan to eat.  The rice will be kept warm until I do eat.  The cooking time is only a hassle if one does not plan ahead.  There is a remedy for this, however, you can buy Minute Brand Instant Rice instead.Now, I have one HUGE complaint here, but it has nothing to do with the manufacturer or the rice cooker.  My complaint is again Amazon.  They shipped this $200 rice cooker to me in the manufacturer's box.  No shipping box was used.  Somewhere along the way, either they dropped it really hard or something big and sharp fell on it because there was a HUGE gash on one side of the box, and the box's corners were all smashed in.  Who in his right mind ships a $200 piece of computerised equipment without a shipping box?Then, to add insult to injury, the delivery person simply opened my gate and left the rice cooker sitting in the muddy wet grass (we had a lot of rain the day before, and it still was not dry out) even though there was a DRY, CLEAN sidewalk right next to where he left it.  Moreover, it was only a very few more feet to to walk to reach my garden bench beneath my covered porch where it not only could have been left in a dry area protected from rain and also further from the gate where someone could have spied it and reached inside to grab it.  This just shows a lack of attention and concern in the delivery.I have had to complain at least 4-5 times in the last few months about Amazon drivers leaving my packages OUTSIDE of my gate where they are very likely to be stolen.  I cannot wrap my head around how these drivers must think if they would leave packages outside of the gate or leave packages inside the gate but in the muddy grass even though the dry, safe porch is only a few more feet away.29 July 21 ETA:  I have now prepared Jasmine rice, steel cut oats, aka Irish oats, wild rice blend, and long grain parboiled rice in this machine, and they all turned out great.  The only one I was concerned about was the long grain parboiled rice, but I need not have worried.  I prepared 1 cup rice to 1.25 cups water and cooked it on Mixed, and it turned out just fine.  Be sure to wash you rice before cooking, though.  I forgot to wash the wild rice blend, and it turned out too sticky for wild rice.  I used the rice/water ratio of 1 cup rice to 1.5 cups water and used the brown rice setting per the Zojirushi website.  I thought the mixed rice setting is for rice with other items added, e.g. veggies, but I think the next time I will try the mixed rice setting because after all, I used a blend of black, brown, red, and wild rice.  It may turn out better on the mixed rice setting, and it should turn out better if I remember to rinse it of course.  This is an object in mindfulness.  If we let too many things distract us at once, then we cannot focus on a simple task well enough to do a proper job.  Making rice can be very Zen if you are in the moment.Conclusion: this rice cooker will cook most rices just fine including parboiled long grain rice, and I am now very happy indeed.  I really wish I would have purchased one of the Zojirushi rice cookers 2-3 ago at the time I first became interested in them.  Two things held me back.  Firstly, I thought the rice cooker would not be able to cook long grain parboiled rice which is my go-to rice, and secondly, I did not think I could add other ingredients to my rice, e.g. veggies.  I was wrong on BOTH counts.  If these are issues that have held you back, do not let them.  This rice cooker is quite versatile.For example, I made Jasmine rice in the cooker one day.  I added an whole, fresh tomato and a splash of olive oil to the pot. I saw a chef do this on YouTube.  It turned out great.  I added my usual Lipton Beefy Onion Soup Mix to my long grain parboiled rice, and it turned out great, too.  I will continue to experiment, but at this point, I think this rice cooker could cook pretty much any type of rice you care to put into it, and do not fear adding veggies and even some minced pieces of lean meat if you eat meat.Given the range of grains I can cook in this rice cooker and the ease of using and cleaning it, I am very pleased with this rice cooker.  I am less pleased with Amazon at the moment, though.  If you decide to purchase one, remember to stipulate that it be sent in Amazon packaging IF you care about the manufacturer box arriving in good shape.ETA:  Well, I have been using my rice cooker for over a year now!  I cannot believe I have had it that long already!  I still love it and use pretty much every single day.  I did want to add a caveat to my review, though.The instructions say to be sure to wipe off any moisture from the bottom of the cooking before you place it in the base and use it.  I never gave it much thought as to why, but I always wiped it, or so I thought.  It seems I used it a couple of time whilst there was still moisture on the outside bottom of the bowl, and that moisture sort of "baked" into the metal where you place the bowl.  I tried to unsuccessfully to scrub it out. It seems permanent.  I cannot budge it.  It appears to be cosmetic only, but it bothers me nonetheless.  I am happy that the rice cooker still performs just fine, but every time I remove the bowl and see those marks, it bothers me.  Once this rice cooker has to be replaced, next time I will be very, very careful to remove all moisture from the bottom of the bowl before I place it into the base to cook rice or anything else.  Attaching a photo for you so you can see what it looks like.  Wish I could figure out a way to clean off of these ugly, dark "burns."  I am not really sure what to call them.  I guess it must be the minerals in the water that were baked on or burned into the metal?  If anyone knows how to remove these "burns," please let the rest of us know.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Andy' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart Fondue Pot, 3 Quart, For Chocolate, Cheese, Broth, Oil, Stainless Steel, CFO-3SSP1'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 63.08; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Electric Fondue Pots'.
output:
Not good. Flawed design.: Flawed design.
This pot uses an on-off relay wired to the thermostat. What does that mean? It's like a light switch. The heat source is either on full blast, or off. So as you heat up, it's on full blast until the contents hit the target temp. Then the burner is off until the temp drops below the trigger temp, then the burner is on full blast until the target temp again.
So what? Well, it's not so much of a big deal when the bowl is full and there is a big thermal mass, but when you are getting down to the end, the cheese burns when the heater turns on and then it solidifies when it turns off. The cheese separates to glue and oil.
They should have used a pulse width modulator and a logic circuit to throttle the heat source to maintain a constant output.
I don't know how it works for oil or chocolate, didn't try.

output: Absolute crap and a fraud.: This thing is an absolute POS and a fraud.  The motor is NOT 1000 watts, it's a weak motor with an inertia flywheel.  God help you if you put a couple carrots or apples in.  The motor nearly slows to a halt.  Then you have to wait 20+ seconds or so for the feeble motor to gather enough speed before making another futile attempt at juicing.While we're talking about juicing, be forewarned, if all you ever want to juice is celery, kale, carrot, potatoes, and apple, then this is the juicer for you.It will NOT juice oranges, grapefruit, cherries, strawberries, blueberries, pomegranate, banana, mango, melon, raspberries, blackberries, lemon, lime, tangerine, etc....Yes, I am fully aware of the "slow speed" function on the "juicer" for "soft fruit".  All this does is grind up whatever it can and chucks it immediately in the pulp can.  ...that is until it gets down to the last 1/2" or so, then it just takes the entire thing and chucks it in the pulp can.I bought this thing because I do not want a masticating juicer.  I wanted an efficient juicer that WORKED and was durable enough to stand up to many years of heavy use.  Holy hell was I WRONG!.  I am shocked the motor held out long enough to make the couple dozen "glasses" I did manage to coax out of it.  I seriously doubt the motor is strong enough to withstand the strain from the inertial flywheel for more than a month.  It's ALREADY audibly and significantly SLOWER than it was after the first 4 attempts.Clean up easy?  Not even close.  After you spend about an hour trying despirately to coax juice out of this POS using different prep cut lengths, different pressures, or even no pressure at all, you are THEN treated to about 20-25 minutes of clean up.  The lid to this thing is plastic, and entire chunks of fruit are launched at it at light speed, so naturally, it gets scratched, gouged, and roughed up.  Which you then have to scrub to get all the crap out of it, thus making even MORE scratches for bacteria, virus', and filth to hid in.  Good thing the advert said this was ALL STAINLESS STEEL!!!  Then you get to disassemble the entire thing, which is the ONLY decent thing about this POS.  Forget about the brush they give you.  All that is good for is spending 15-20 minutes scrubbing the crap out of the screen, both sides, twice, at LEAST, to get all the food off.  For everything else, you need a myriad of tools.  A custom bottle brush to clean the inside of the juice shute, another bottle brush with long bristles to clean up under the lip in the juice catch, then you still have to do some sponge kung-fu in order to attempt to get all the food out of all the tight, small, inside, 3 corner areas.  FUN!!!  EASY!!!Oh, I forgot to mention, then you have to clean the motor base where juice leaked all over it, and underneath it as well, where the juice leaks all over the side of itself.  I mean, unless you want to pick it up, tilt it, and try and shake all the juice out while the catch can is still there.  It's still going to drip all over itself and it's going to run underneath and into the treaded rubber feet.I don't know what I'll do for a juicer now.  I guess I have to buy a real commercial one.  Because apparently, this one is NOT!  Even according to Breville's website.  I guess the big "COMMERCIAL" sticker on the side of this thing is sarcasm.  Not fraud.  Oh, no.  Never.For now, I will just have to fight the urge to smash this thing through the skull of anyone with the misfortune of having an Australian accent and raiding his pockets for my $300.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Heidi7' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart Fondue Pot, 3 Quart, For Chocolate, Cheese, Broth, Oil, Stainless Steel, CFO-3SSP1'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 63.08; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Electric Fondue Pots'.
output:
Pretty, functional and perfect size: I have only used it once so far; I have tried various heat settings and it seems to work well. It simmers, boils and keeps warm, respectively, well on different heat settings. The reasons why I am giving it 4 stars instead are:

1.) It does not come with a lid; it will simmer much quicker with a lid.

2.) It would be so much better if the pot could be detached from the base where the electric plug is for easier and safer cleaning. Now I would need to be very careful not to submerge it in water and not let any water go in the plug as I wash the pot. Not an annoyance but it takes a longer time to clean due to that.

All in all, it looks pretty and functions well. I would recommend it.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'S.R' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart WMR-CAP2 Round Classic Waffle Maker, Brushed Stainless,Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 29.95; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: Best addition to our weekend brunch: This little waffle maker made our weekend brunch so much more enjoyable. I was afraid that it was going to be one of those kitchen gadgets that would collect dust, but not at our house. It’s compact and easy to use and we use it often. It’s totally non stick and easy to clean. I debated if I should buy a bigger one to cook multiple waffles at once, but this heats up and cooks quickly . So it’s enough for two of us to eat without waiting.Why 4 stars, not 5? There are two things I would change. 1. I wish the power cable is longer as we use it on the table. 2. I wish there is a mechanism to keep it closed so that we can store it vertically. We use a thick rubber band for that. Otherwise no complaints.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'jhalaks' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Upgrade of Zojirushi NS-MYC10: I wanted to submit my review here based on the older model that I had purchased.The perfect rice cooker: Zojirushi NS-MYC10I've had this rice cooker for more than 6yrs and use it to cook rice every single day. It makes 11 cups of cooked rice.The 5.5 cup volume is a little misleading for us Indians. We normally cook rice, rice:water = 1:2 ratio. So basically this rice cooker cooks a max of 3 3/4 cups of rice (using the cup provided).You will be astonished at the difference in taste between the rice cooked here versus some other cooker. I'm not exaggerating as I've two different rice cookers, the other one being Sanyo.I love the fuzzy logic feature where you can cook different rices & porridge's. The delayed time setting is a blessing... when I bought it at the end of 2005, nobody else had the delayed time setting. Obviously there are newer models now.For a family of 4 (2 kids below ages of 8yrs), this is just the perfect size!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'SK' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Excellent, reliable rice cooker: This rice cooker is a delight to use. Not only does it make the rice perfectly every time, but it's also easy to use and sings a cute little song when it's turned on and when the rice is done. I use the timer feature all the time.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Sherry McCardell' to comment on the product 'BLACK+DECKER G48TD Waffle Maker, 3-in-1, Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 69.99; Brand: BLACK+DECKER; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.

The medal clip that's suppose to hold the lower plate down does not do the job. Every time I lift the top when checking on a waffle or taking one out to cook another one, the clip let's go and the lower plate lifts out of position. It's a;most impossible to get it down into position, because by now the clip is too hot to touch to be able to clip it back into place.Also, the handle on the top gets very hot and you need a hot pad to lift it up when getting a waffle out of the maker.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Jomama' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Its great... BUT...: so this is probably my 5th Zojirushi rice cooker.  One I gave away, I've had issues with 3 of the other 4.  1st one lasted about 4-5 years - totally worth it & I never had issues with it.  2nd one I gave away when we moved.  3rd one is still working in our second home.  4th one I had to throw away after less than a year because we had dropped the internal pot and it bent slightly and would never seal again causing the rice to harden after just a few hours of cooking (We tried to get a new internal pot, but it was next to impossible to get and when I think I found one it was as much as a new cooker). That led me to our current one - We ALWAYS have a pot of rice ready to eat, and lately its been getting hard again - the internal pot isn't damaged - I finally figured out the lid just won't seal completely!  I'm frustrated.  I LOVE this rice cooker - so much so i've bought one for several family members and friends!  Guess i should have gotten the extended warranty!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Space Tacos' to comment on the product 'Omega Nutrition Center Juicer (Discontinued by Manufacturer)'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 279.98; Brand: Omega; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Masticating Juicers'.
output: Still Works: I bought this several years ago, and even though I haven't been a religious juicer, it still works great. I recently decided to start juicing in the morning as much as I can (Like leafy greens and apples so it doesn't take forever). This juicer does great with leafy greens but not with fruit. Carrots and hard veggies, if cut, does a great job but it is a pain in the but to pre-cut everything. But I do it so it's easier on the machine.Even though it doesn't juice fruit well, it makes great sorbets! Just add frozen fruit. So easy. Cleaning is also easy, just rinse everything or throw it in the dish washer like I do. Overall, I don't have much complaints except the preparation. Bu I bought this machine because it was cheaper than the other style juicers, and reliable and slow enough not to damage the live enzymes. My juicer also came with a 10 year warranty so that's good.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'David Murad' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NHS-06 3-Cup (Uncooked) Rice Cooker, White (-WB)'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 51.82; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Perfect rice every time!: I use this rice cooker almost every day. It is so simple that not even a monkey could mess it up. Add the desired amount of rice, fill water to line, press button down, then wait for rice to finish cooking.Pros:Simplicity: 5/5You literally just need to push the button down and it makes you your rice and it is cooked to perfection every time.Durability: 5/5Has held up well over the test of time. It’s a very simple device so I expect it to last for years to come. It reminds me of old appliances that used to be unbreakable and lasted forever.Cleaning: 5/5The lid and rice container are the only things that get dirty and they are easily detached from the heating element and extremely easy to clean. I’m pretty sure the rice container is nonstick and cleans like a dream. The lid is glass and is also very easy to clean by hand. Both are machine washable and come out sparkling if you want to do it that way, but it takes less than 2 minutes to clean by hand so I usually just do that.Cons:Messy: 4/5It’s honestly not that messy, but there is a steam release hole on the lid which releases steam. The steam can contain some starches and leaves a small film on the lid and if the steam vent is close to something like a cabinet or a wall it will get a small starchy film on it. Easily wipes clean with just water and doesn’t stain at all though.TLDR: this is an amazing product and if you make rice a lot it will work very well for you. Zojirushi is a gold standard for a reason. You can get fancier models that do extra stuff, but if you just want to cook rice then look no further.I highly recommend this rice cooker!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Wayne' to comment on the product 'Presto 04830 PowerPop Microwave Multi-Popper, Black'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 24.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Popcorn Poppers'.
output: Use lower power than full on.: Thinner than the original from several years ago.  This is our second one of the 'new' generation, with thinner plastic. We have to use power at 90% rather than full power to avoid overheating. We don't use oil, and add clarified butter and salt after popping.  Great popcorn, we use organic from our local grocery bulk supplies. Orville's seems too puffy.after 2 years use, the last one became discoloerd, and the peformance got erratic.  The new one works well, though as noted above.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Sue' to comment on the product 'BLACK+DECKER G48TD Waffle Maker, 3-in-1, Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 69.99; Brand: BLACK+DECKER; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: Worthless (and Dangerous!) After a Year: It was great in the beginning, but even with attentive care and cleaning within a matter of months it is useless and dangerous.1) the nonstick fails quickly2) the heat distribution is so uneven that only the center of the griddle is usable.3) the clips that hold the plates in loosen quickly, so now they're trying to slide from side to side as you're cooking because they don't sit flush (as a other reviewer demonstrated).So allow me to put these things together to demonstrate the devastation. Upon opening, the waffle batter you just made presents like a feral dog with peanut butter in it's jaws- it's now burnt in some places, wet in others, and your waffles are simultaneously dripping and burning to both grill plates. So you begin to scrape as much off as you can, but when you touch it with the spatula, the grill plate shifts above the handle and you burn your knuckles. You fight with it for another 5 min while you wait for wet spots to cook a bit more, burnt spots to burn further so they can actually be scraped off, and now your house is filled with that awful smell of failure. You limp the process along by making a lopsided waffle in the center of the grill plates, but still need to pray to several Gods to squeak 2 waffles out unharmed.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Eli Hunter' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: If you're considering buying this, BUY IT: I was initially skeptical of spending over $200 on a rice cooker. However, if you're willing to even consider spending that much on a rice cooker, you should spend that much on this rice cooker. You know how much good rice is worth to you.Now, when I go to restaurants and have their rice, I think of my Zojirushi because their rice is never as good as my rice at home. Having rice only for dinner used to be a struggle meal. But now I happily eat a bowl of rice with soy sauce as a small dinner or snack.The rice comes out perfectly consistent every time, neither too firm nor too sticky. My only possible, minor complaint is that it takes about 45 minutes to cook rice. But that's a small price to pay for perfect rice.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Suzanne T.' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 290.95; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: A mack truck: I LOVE this juicer!  It handles every and anything you throw at it and plows right through it.  I added this to my Wish List, kept an eye on it and lucked out; I got from an amazon warehouse deal for $201.  I was soooo happy!  I purchased the square trade 3 year warranty, just in case, as it did not cost much (about $30 bucks) and gives added peace of mind.  Came in the original box, no scratches, etc.  It's pretty perfect. It's big, so you need a place for it, but it's beautiful, so I'm ok with leaving it out. There are a bunch of parts, but nothing unreasonable.  Soak the mesh filter just a couple of minutes and use the included brush or buy a cheap one elsewhere to clean the screen. Mine came with two (!) though I find my cheap little Ikea (2 for 99 cents) kitchen brush works just as well.  One piece of advise: Use WARM WATER to clean the plastic parts (including the pitcher).  I read some reviews that say those parts get "cloudy" or murky-looking over time; hot water will do that to plastic.  Use warm water and it should stay looking good much longer.  Happy juicing!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'EAK' to comment on the product 'BLACK+DECKER G48TD Waffle Maker, 3-in-1, Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 69.99; Brand: BLACK+DECKER; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: Poor Quality Doesn't last: I have had 2 of these appliances. When they work they do a decent job. My first one failed under warranty and was replaced by B&D. This second one lasted until 6 months after the warranty expired. The unit wouldn't turn on. It went in the trash. I've read some of the reviews. The plates do not securely fit in the unit. There is movement. I have made waffles and pancakes weekly for several years and have been satisfied with the results. However, this appliance will not last as long as older ones did. China cannot make reliable appliances. Fortunately this is cheap enough to be able to replace it every few years, sadly. I am limited by space in my cabinet so this is the only type appliance that fits the bill. When we do business with China, you have to lower your standards!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Sarah A' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart Food Processor, Mini-Prep 3 Cup, 24 oz, Brushed Chrome and Nickel, DLC-2ABC'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 39.95; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Food Processors'.
output: Great little machine: I bought my first mini prep in 2012. After 10 years, the plastic that holds the blades is starting to get a couple cracks so I'm getting another. But the machine still works beautifully. I mainly just make bread or cracker crumbs and sometimes grind a bit of beef either roasted or raw in it. But I've used it for lots of things in the past. It does everything they claim, and well. There isn't a slicer or grater attachment but I have a grater and a mandolin, I've no need for extra attachments to store anyway and they don't ever work great besides.No food processor is going to for instance chop onions the way you might want; I don't even use it for that. I chop my onions with a knife and a cutting board which are even easier to clean than this is and about as fast. Very easy to clean. They say best not in dishwasher but I just pull the lid, etc. off there and put them in the dishwasher (top rack only) yet no damage showed up for 10 years. Sometimes I want a bigger one but this works better than any full sized food processor I've ever used so I'm sticking with it.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'GORT' to comment on the product 'Presto 02970 Professional SaladShooter Electric Slicer/Shredder, Black,1 count'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 73.49; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Electric Utensils:Electric Slicers'.
output: Presto 02970 Professional SaladShooter - “Mozzarella Machine”: Have struggled over years past in shredding 2 lbs of mozzarella for my holiday lasagna. This machine was a game changer. Placed two 1 lb mozzarella packages in the freezer for 45 min prior to shredding using the medium shredding cone. Shredded both pieces within a few minutes unlike my original shred by hand lengthya method. Uggghhh !!  All the presto parts are removable for cleaning. Nice unit.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Derek' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Need Perfect Rice?: Received my new rice cooker with great expectations after reading too many reviews and doing too much research. I decided to do this after hearing my wife complain again that she can never get rice to turn out right on the stove.I'm a practical shopper, so I first looked at basic cookers, then got into the fuzzy logic ones. I decided on the Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 5 1/2 cup because it had all the advantages of making perfect rice and if it did, which it does, would be a good buy with no regrets. There are more expensive ones that have induction heat, but my real goal was just to have great rice.If I had to do it all over again, I may look more closely at the Tiger sold at Costco for less money, however I'm really happy with what I got.So far I've made 3 batches of white rice, one of brown, and one batch of oatmeal.  Everything came out perfect.  I really like the keep warm feature, you can go for several hours.  The lid pops open when you push the button and has a nice seal that keeps the moisture in. The retractable cord seems overkill for a tabletop appliance, but it is convenient, you can retract the cord and take it to the table if you want.  Cleans up easy, nice non-stick surface on the bowl and the lid has an insert that comes apart easily.The directions explain about rice type and the different settings available. To an amature rice consumer, it's pretty confusing, but it comes down to just using 1 of the two measuring cups provided, filling to the correct line with water, then selecting a program.It makes plenty of rice for our family of 4 with leftovers.

output: Not the best choice for a small work space.: The Breville BJE200XL Compact Juice does not live up to the name, "Compact" if your workspace is limited.  It juices very well and cleanup is not too demanding, but the juicer carries a large footprint on the counter top.  More than that, it would not fit under the upper cabinets in my kitchen which forced me to position the juicer at the very edge of my counter top to insert anything I wanted to juice.  In addition, storing the juicer presented its own set of challenges.Be that as it may, it is a powerful appliance and performed well juicing a variety of fruits and vegetables.I would highly recommend the product with the following advice:  study the overall measurements before committing to a purchase particularly if your kitchen is small and/or your counter top space is limited.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Amazon Customer' to comment on the product 'Presto 06003 Options Electric Multi-Cooker/Steamer'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 40.78; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Steamers'.
output: A "Safety feature" that doesn't allow the Device to operate properly isn't a Safety feature!!!: We had a Dazey Chef's Pot for 30 years...and loved it... but it (and its control) were getting a bit scary.SO....we bought this.I have not turned it on yet...but I don't need to in order to write this review.The magnetic "Safety Feature" on the control is so weak (read: "safe") that it disconnects if you do more than *look* at the control or it's cord... anywhere on the cord.I cannot imagine trying to adjust the temperature while it is connected and turned-on...This is completely unacceptable. I would love to know what shaved monkeys that Presto hired to impersonate Engineers designed this piece of garbage?(I should note that the User's Manual provided a CYA:)"The magnetic cord was designed to detach easily from the heat control. As a result, if bumped or touched during use, it could detach and cause the multi-cooker to stop heating. Avoid contact with the magnetic cord during operation."I would amend that to "...WILL detach and cause the multi-cooker to stop heating."I checked the old Dazey DTC-1 Probe... but Presto very carefully designed the heater connections at a different span diameter; so that you can't use the old Probe to replace the Junk version.I will be purchasing a "Presto 6900 Electric Griddle Heat Control" to replace this useless dreck.The specs appear identical to the new Control...without the "safety" feature.You have been warned; Good Luck.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'KC' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart Fondue Pot, 3 Quart, For Chocolate, Cheese, Broth, Oil, Stainless Steel, CFO-3SSP1'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 63.08; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Electric Fondue Pots'.
output: Best Fondue Pot I have owned!!: I LOVE this fondue pot!! I have owned several fondue pots over the last 20years and this is the best one yet!!  It is so easy to use, easy to clean and stores nicely!  I researched a lot before buying this fondue pot and I can say that its the best fondue pot out there.  I have actually bought 3 of this fondue pot.  My hubby and I loved it soo much that we bought it for a friends wedding who decided to have fondue for their reception.  Everyone was asking where we bought, how much it was and saying how quick and easy it was to use! I think we made some sales that day!  LOL..I have 2 at home since we usually do a 3 course fondue night dinner.. The clean up on the pots is soo fast, just a little soap and a quick wipe gets rid of everything which means no scrubbing between courses!!  The pot heats up amazingly fast!!  I think it took less than 2 min. to heat up a FULL pot of Coq Au Vin sauce for cooking our meats/seafood.  Infact it was soo fast that I didn't have time to do all my preparation I ususally do when I have to wait for the sterno to heat up my old fondue pot and had to have help.I love the fact that the pot has a wide mouth to it.  It allows many fondue forks to be able to be sitting in the pot at once. I think we had 5 people in one pot at the wedding which is a lot considering each person had 2 forks in the pot at once.  The temperature control is fantastic!! With so many sticks in the pot, we just turned up the temperature a little and there was no waiting to cook the food because the temperature had dropped, then you have to wait for it to heat up again.I no longer have burnt Cheese fondue because I couldn't control the heat on my sterno fondue pots.  I like the fact that I have a good temperature on my chocolate and it doesn't sear half of your tastebuds off because its just too hot.Oh, and I didn't mention... you can put it in the dishwasher!!!!!  SOO easy.  I like to wash by hand but the hubby is all about the dishwasher cleaning it.  Not that it matters because everything comes off of the inside soooo easily.The only disappointment I had was the short cord, but it really wasn't a big deal since we just plugged it into an extension cord.Overall I would totally recommend this pot to someone who is wanting a great fondue pot, or someone who is scared to take the plunge for an electric fondue pot.. TOTALLY WORTH THE MONEY!!!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Ski9' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Great for people who like many rice varieties: I just bought this older model in 2019.  It seems very successful because it's been manufactured for a long time, and still it is listed as a "current" model on Zojirushi's website. I don't regret the purchase because it is probably best for me in the 1 liter (5.5 cup) range (same for 1.8 L), but as I note below, it has some downsides that made me a little disappointed.  I was interested in the spherical heating element, the handles on the inner bowl, the extended keep-warm function, the retractable power cord, and the many varieties of rice settings. I would recommend something cheaper and/or newer if you mostly want to use it for white rice. But if you like a variety of rices, including different degrees of "brown-ness" and hardness then this is really one of the best in this price range, I think. That's probably why the model has stuck around for so long.  BUT, the newer models have a "steam" function which this does NOT. So, the current description on Amazon's page for the item is WRONG. A similar, newer "Made in Japan" model for roughly same price (with removable cord, and fewer rice varieties, and newer steam vent design) does have "Steam" function and the description for the two is incorrectly duplicated here. I am still glad I got this one.I have a 3 cup Zojirushi, the NS-LAC05 that I bought about 10 years ago, which is very similar to the current NS-LGC05 and NS-LHC05, and I wanted a bigger one. My 3-cup cooker is made in China like most Zojirushi models, and if you want this "Neuro-Fuzzy" because it is "Japanese," then in my experience that's a bad reason to choose a Zojirushi model. (Incidentally, my old cooker also had "Neuro-Fuzzy written on the manual cover, so that is not a tech unique to this model.)  They are all Japanese (just like iPhone is not a "Chinese" phone, just expertly assembled there -- so to that extent, yes it is Chinese). You just pay extra for the "Made in Japan" prominently printed on front, for no good reason. Or rather, a very bad reason, because my older cooker seems like more high-quality construction.  This one is in some ways less thoughtfully made, to make up for the more expensive cost of labor, is my guess. For example, when you open the door, you can see exposed screws, and exposed inside of the plastic part of the lid, which does not look nice. The Chinese-made models have an extra piece of plastic to cover up the screws and makes the inside look nice. I care about aesthetics and details like that.  And I like to leave the lid open much of the time, with inner lid gently placed on the bowl, when the cooker is not in use because it seems better for the gaskets, plus it airs things out. But this model looks too unpleasant that way so I will probably keep it closed.  (Not sure whether open or closed is best for the gasket, or if it matters.) Also, my 3-cup model has nice metal parts on the outside, and this one is all plastic, although nice smooth high-quality plastic. And the lid-opening button is nicer and possibly sturdier on the Chinese-made models. But the thing I like the most about my 3-cup one over this model is the steam vent. I think it is an advancement over this older model. It has an upper compartment to collect the extra moisture, so there is an additional cover-piece and gasket on top. And it is easier to wipe the steam vent clean in the inside of the lid for the newer design. Again, more fancy construction with more parts, which may be why the more simple design of the NS-ZCC models is still cost-effective to manufacture in Japan.  And the better-constructed lids are almost certainly more resistant to warping from heat.One important thing to note about this model is that it was designed for the Japanese market, where "regular" rice is short or medium grain, not the long-grain I'm used to. I often buy nice quality organic Jasmine or Basmati. On my old cooker, there was a "white/mixed" setting and a separate "sushi" setting, whereas on this one there is "regular/sushi" and a separate "mixed."  I think my long grain rice cooks better with the "mixed" setting rather than "regular" on this model.  The first time I cooked it with regular setting, it was really disgusting mush, so I tried the "mixed" and then it was nice. But I also took care to rinse the rice super well (at least 4 times rather than 3 like last time) so that may have helped, too. And I used water up to the mark rather than a bit extra (the manual says to use extra water with long grain but says nothing about proper menu selection). The "mixed" setting does not get as hot, to keep it from boiling over. So anyway, this may explain the mixed reviews for this product, with many people loving it and some people having very bad experience.  "Regular" in Japan is not really "regular" in most places, because most places tend to use long-grained rice. One downside of using the "mixed" instead of "white/sushi" setting is that extended keep warm is not settable for "mixed" since they want you to keep only white rice for extended time in it. But I don't keep rice for more than ~10 hours and the regular "keep warm" was fine for me for several hours. [UPDATE: The mush on my first try was my fault; the rice I used just needs to be rinsed really well because it has lots of starch. When I rinse really well, it turns out excellent on the "Regular" setting also. And American Long Grain did not have this issue. So it is not a cooker problem at all, and long-grain rice can be cooked on regular setting and used with extended keep-warm.]Two bad things about the Zojirushi models, probably all of them: 1) the irreplaceable battery, which means after a few years you will need to keep it plugged in if you don't want to reset the clock. Yes, you can ship it in for servicing but that's very expensive just for the battery and I did not (and will not) do it for my 3-cup model. One reviewer wrote (I forget for which model) that this is consumer-hostile and I absolutely agree. What kind of clock (or watch) do you have to send in to the manufacturer to replace the battery? It is outrageous and inconsiderate. I might figure out how to solder in a replacement battery myself, before I would spend so much money (and be without my cooker) for replacing.  2) The second bad thing is the super expensive replacement bowls and other parts. All non-stick surfaces will eventually wear out, and Zojirushi replacement is ~$50-70 for the bowls. You can buy a normal (non-fuzzy) rice cooker for under $20! And many nice fancier than bare-bones cookers for under the price of a replacement bowl (the bowls are very nice, though, and high quality).  An inner lid replacement (which you may need if the gasket is damaged) is ~$22-28. The tiny spatula holder, which seems like it is worth under a dollar, is nearly $5, though to be fair, all prices on their site include shipping. Plus at least you have the option to order replacements. The spatula holder is not easily removable without damage (because it has plastic hooks that allow it to slide in one direction) and I broke mine when I yanked it out for cleaning. But not worth the cost of replacement. How do the parts prices compare to those for, say, Instant Pot? And expensive cooking equipment really should have replacement parts available for parts that wear out. I would not buy from a company that did not offer that. But the prices are totally unreasonable for the Zoji parts. So as with the battery, this is very consumer-hostile and for this reason I seriously considered shopping for another brand. But the cooker is excellent otherwise, so I stuck with this brand.One last note about the non-stick surface: the important thing for protecting it is not so much the material that comes in contact with it but the smoothness of it. A non-smooth metal utensil is more likely to cause damage than a non-smooth plastic one, but plastic utensils can cause damage, too. The plastic spatula that came with my 3-cup model was not very smooth and that's why my 3-cup bowl got damaged, since I never used other utensils inside the bowl. The new spatula that came with this ZCC model looks almost identical but is slightly softer plastic and also very smooth. So, feel the edge of the utensil that you use inside the bowl, and don't use it if it does not feel smooth, even if it is plastic. And in any case be super gentle even with any plastic or wooden utensil. As far as toxicity, the Teflon coatings manufactured since 2013 should all be safe (and probably most manufacturers phased out the questionable type coating long before then). If you do research from reputable sources on this topic, I think you'll find that there is no evidence that the very inert material in these coatings is harmful. Almost everything is toxic in large-enough quantities, and you are not consuming gobs of coating. So that's something to keep in mind when considering whether or not to replace an old Zoji bowl.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Chrissie' to comment on the product 'Cuisinart Fondue Pot, 3 Quart, For Chocolate, Cheese, Broth, Oil, Stainless Steel, CFO-3SSP1'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 63.08; Brand: Cuisinart; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Electric Fondue Pots'.
output: Love this!: I love this!  After many years of dealing with open flame and little or no control over the temperature, this is sweet!  Clean up was a breeze compared to my old cast iron pot.  I am a little concerned about the use of metal forks with the non-stick surface.  So far I have avoided this by using wooden skewers. instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Red' to comment on the product 'Omega Nutrition Center Juicer (Discontinued by Manufacturer)'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 279.98; Brand: Omega; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Masticating Juicers'.
output: Great juicer...3 yrs later still a great juicer: (FOLLOW UP REVIEW APRIL 2012)I've owned this juicer for nearly 3 yrs and used it almost daily since i first bought it.  All i can say is that I'm surprised that i don't have a single shred of buyers remorse with this purchase and i usually do with almost everything that I buy. It works the same today as the first day which i find to be rare with appliances these days.  Since 3 years ago, i've continued my research in juicers and i periodically check if there is a better one out there.  There are tons of juicer comparison videos online and I encourage all of you to watch them before making your purchase decision.  What i've learned in the past 3 years is that there are 4 main types of juicers: centrifugal, single auger, twin gear, and hydraulic press.  If your top priority is maximum juice quality and yield for the broadest scope of fruits and vegetables then you can ignore centrifugal type juicers...in my opinion.  When comparing single auger, twin gear and hydraulic press type juicers i find that the difference in juice quality and yield is small.  I've thought long and hard about upgrading to a twin gear and even a hydraulic press type juicer over the past 3 yrs but i just can't justify spending the extra $500-$2500 (Greenstar to Norwalk) for negligible increase in quality and yield.  If money and preparation time was of no concern of mine i might feel differently.  In summary, if your top priority is quality and yield then you get the biggest bang for your buck with a low rpm single auger type juicer like the omega 8003-8006.Cons:1. One thing the the omega 8003 doesn't do well is making nut milks like almond milk or soy milk.  I don't ever make those so it's not an issue with me but if it is perhaps a vertical single auger juicer like the omega vrt, kurvings silent juicer or Hurom vertical juicer is right for you.  (I would be cautious with the kurvings and Hurom brands because they haven't been around as long so they might not be around to honor the warranty.)2. A common complaint is that the feed tube is small which requires the user to slice up the produce more than they would have to if using another style juicer.  I agree that the in an ideal world the feed tube would be larger but my concern there would be that a larger feed tube would put larger chunks of produce through the machine possibly requiring a more powerful and more expensive motor.  The small diameter feed tube doesn't necessarily require more prep time...it depends on what you are juicing.  When juicing carrots, i find that baby carrots require no prep and provide the same yield as regular carrots.  Kale, chard, celery, collard greens, etc...will fit right in the machine without any cutting.  So I find that the small inlet diameter isn't a big deal to me but just know that some people complain about it.If you're interested in buying this juicer, just know that omega has updated this design and implemented the improvements in the 8004 (white) and 8006 (chrome) models.  They've updated the material of the auger to GE Ultem which is a plastic that is 8 times harder than the 8003's melamine auger.  They've also improved the juicer cone design to improve it's strength and added 5 more yrs to the products warranty (15 yr total!).  Less significant design changes are the design of the collection cups and shell of the motor.  These updates are significant enough that if i were to purchase a juicer now i would get the 8004 with the extended warranty, updated juicer cone design and harder auger.My goal in this review is to help the reader avoid making the same trial and error mistakes that i did with buying and ultimately returning different juicers until i finally bought this one.  let my review here be a testament to how satisfied I am with this juicer.  People are more likely to write a review of a product that they've had nothing but trouble with.  I takes an extremely satisfied customer to take the time to write an honest review.  So if I sound like I'm over selling this juicer it's only because i'm extremely proud of this purchase.I wish you all the best in your juicing endeavors and if you have any questions please post a comment as I love sharing my knowledge and passion for healthy living.(ORIGINAL REVIEW SEPT 2009)I wanted to get into juicing so I started researching juicers on Amazon.  I originally bought the Breville BJE200XL.  This juicer is very popular on this site and received good reviews.  I beg to differ.  It was cumbersome, difficult to clean, and the juice didn't taste very good.  I immediately returned this juicer and did more research.  In my opinion, if you're serious about juicing I would highly recommend the Omega 8003.  It's quiet, easy to clean, and produces great tasting, high quality juice.  It's worth every penny and i'll never make the mistake of buying a centrifugal juicer again.

Product price: 138.07; Brand: Breville; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Centrifugal Juicers'.
output: I've been pretty happy with Breville's Juice Fo...: I've always been a fan of starting my day with a fresh glass of juice, and Breville's Juice Fountain Compact Juicer has been the perfect addition to my morning routine. With its powerful extraction, this juicer effortlessly turns even the toughest fruits and vegetables into a delicious and nutritious drink. It's like having a professional juicer right in my own kitchen! The compact design is also a major plus, as it doesn't take up much counter space. However, if there's one area that could be improved, it's the durability. While the juicer has performed admirably so far, I can't help but wonder if it will stand the test of time. But overall, I'm thrilled with my purchase and look forward to many more glasses of refreshing juice with Breville's Juice Fountain Compact Juicer.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'andrew tasso' to comment on the product 'Omega Nutrition Center Juicer (Discontinued by Manufacturer)'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 279.98; Brand: Omega; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Masticating Juicers'.
output: This juicer is great. Runs very quiet and the clean up is ...: This juicer is great. Runs very quiet and the clean up is super easy (takes about a minute). Great price for the quality. Higher quality models have stronger auger and bigger feed tube. They are also 100 to 200 dollars more. I have had no issues as of yet with the auger being not hard enough. Just remember to cycle soft and hard produce and the machine should operate fine and not get backed up.The only drawback is that the feed tube could be a little wider. Then I wouldn't have to quarter my cucumbers, would be able to fit in more leafy greens at a time etc. If you want a bigger feed tube, then you should look into the Omega NC800, but I personally couldn't justify spending the extra 100 bucks. I am very happy with this product and am excited about super charging my nutritional regimen!

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Donna Hayden' to comment on the product 'Presto 04830 PowerPop Microwave Multi-Popper, Black'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 24.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Popcorn Poppers'.
output: Powerful Little Popper: My parents have one of these, so I borrowed it to give it a try. Immediately I could tell I needed one too, as I eat popcorn every day. This is a powerful little popper, that pops 1/3 cup popcorn into a full bowl in just three minutes. I put a tablespoon of olive oil in with the kernels and that way the salt sticks. Highly recommend!  I wipe out the bowl and bottom with a paper towel in between uses and only wash it about once a week. Wiping off the cardboard piece in the bottom helps it to pop better each time. I replace the cardboard piece in the bottom once a week.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Roxana Jimenez' to comment on the product 'Breville Juice Fountain Elite Juicer, Brushed Stainless Steel, 800JEXL'. No more than 20 words. output: It leaks everywhere and the juice is not smooth, but full of pulp. I have to strain it to drink it.: After reading the great reviews about this product, I had high hopes and purchased it about 2 months ago. Unfortunately, it leaks juice everywhere, starting from the top. It helps if I put a plastic bag in the cup and clip it, otherwise it sprays juice everywhere. The juice used to be smoother, but now I have to strain it for us to drink it. For someone who juices twice a day, it's extremely disappointing, not to say time-consuming.Juicing takes time, from buying the ingredients, washing and cutting them, and cleaning the juicer! Plus add cleaning the mess the juicer makes and having to strain the juice, it's annoying! I see other people's videos showing how dry the leftovers are. Mine is wet and definitely not dry, quiet a bit of juice going in the plastic bag, instead of the cup! I hope I can still return it, because I threw away the box.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'North Florida Girl' to comment on the product 'Zojirushi NS-ZCC10 Neuro Fuzzy Cooker, 5.5-Cup uncooked rice / 1L, White'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 209.99; Brand: Zojirushi; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Rice Cookers'.
output: Excellent Rice Cooker with many options: Previously, I had an Aroma cooker that never cooked Jasmine rice right.  It always stuck together and was gummy.  And if you didn't unplug immediately after the rice was done the bottom would burn.  Forget about brown rice - never could get that right. Purchased this rice cooker a little over a week ago.  Opened the box and was very pleased with the obvious quality of the cooker.  The next morning I decided to cook some oatmeal in it.  Added rolled oats, water, little salt and butter and turned it on and let it cook while I went out for my morning walk.  After my shower opened rice cooker - oatmeal was hot and perfectly cooked.  And clean up was a breeze.  The leftover oatmeal slide out of the bowl.  The next night I cooked Jasmine rice in it. It was cooked perfectly.  I am going to try to make rice pudding in it tonight.  Things I love about this cooker are its size, quality, non-stick bowl and rice paddle and how easy it is to use.  Makes plenty of rice, even for a family. Amazon has the best price I could find.  I also purchased a rice cooker cookbook with it and am very pleased with it.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Ray NY' to comment on the product 'Presto 04830 PowerPop Microwave Multi-Popper, Black'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 24.99; Brand: Presto; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Specialty Appliances:Popcorn Poppers'.
output: I figured it out how to use it!: So like most people here, I ended up with a burned, black charcoal mess in the middle. I have 1200W microwave. Too strong? I tried less time and wasted more than half the cups. I went through all the reviews and the best advice I found was not to put the popper in the middle. I put it as far to the side I could. It wobbled from side to side but it worked! Almost all of the kernals popped unlike the silicone poppers.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'Marcel Bedard Jr' to comment on the product 'BLACK+DECKER G48TD Waffle Maker, 3-in-1, Silver'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 69.99; Brand: BLACK+DECKER; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Waffle Irons'.
output: This waffle maker is straight up dangerous: This is not a nonstick pan. It requires seasoning. You cannot clean it without soap so be ready to reseason everytime.  I have now attempted four times and all my waffles come out like my picture.  The picture was more olive oil than batter going in. Still stuck.The frame is thinner than your parent's waffle maker, obviously done to cut costs, but what it results in is a frame that warps and puts pressure on the plates to pop out. The temperature regulator device is too tall for the container putting upward pressure on the plate. Combine this with cheap latches and the bottom plate will pull up every time with the waffle. It doesn't stay that way as the waffle will tear apart and the plate will then fall. Don't worry, I caught it with my bare hands.  This issue would've been caught is they had done any level of product testing. I'm sure they did and addressed it placing profit over safety. It feels intentional. This is getting thrown out and I'm definitely reading Black and Decker reviews in the future before buying.Do not buy this product if you want waffles or a safe experience. This is not your parent's waffle maker.

instruction: Please simulate consumer 'R. Spates' to comment on the product 'Omega Nutrition Center Juicer (Discontinued by Manufacturer)'. No more than 20 words. Product price: 279.98; Brand: Omega; NodeLabelPath: 'Home & Kitchen:Kitchen & Dining:Small Appliances:Juicers:Masticating Juicers'.
output: juicers I've known: Omega 8003 I've had for 7 years & it still works beautifully. Because I'm afraid the manuf. is going to change something (cheaper parts, etc.) I'm going to buy another one as a backup.  I've had a Champion=== top of the line--terrible noise & didn't do a good job with leafy greens, forget wheat grass, got strangled with celery (In middle of juicing, I would have to dismantle the Champion to clean out celery "hair" so Champion could continue to function rather than heat up more-- & heating up is a big problem with Champions, per my experience & that of niece, who's a raw chef & our friends)  I've also had a Krups and several other off brands.  For me, the Omega 8003 (or 8005) is built like a Buick-- meant to last.  Yes, you do have to chop up food more than with a Champion, but I'm happy to do this for the results.  My niece, the raw chef, who thought she'd enjoy cutting up less, especially during one of her classes at Whole Foods, bought a Hurom.  She didn't like it...she sold it & went back to her Omega 8003.
